Samanda seychas nujdayetsya v 2300 AZN chtobi kupit nujniye zapchasti dlya pochinki svoyey mashini. Tak kak yeqo mashina isportilas on ne mojet rabotat, yemu v skorom vremeni nujno pochinit yeyo chtobi vosstanovit rabotu.
texts.en: Samandar P. was born in 1961.  He is married and has three children.  Samander, his wife, and their children have been living in Absheron for seven years.  Samander has driven a taxi for eight years.  Before that, he worked as a herdsman and distributed milk and kefir to stores in his car.  Then he decided to become a taxi driver because he would be able to support his family better that way.  Samanda now needs 2300 AZN to buy parts to repair his car.  His car is broken down, and he cannot work.  He needs to repair his car quickly to return to work.

loans.use: kupit nujniye zapchasti dlya remonta mashini

loans.name: Washington

texts.en:
Washington is 28 years old and married with a 1-year-old child and one other dependent. living in Hioma, Uganda. 

He is the sole bread winner of the family and his dream is to have an educated family. 

For five years he has been running a produce business to which he is devoted. He started it by selling goats to get capital.

He faces a challenge of customers not paying. Nevertheless, he hopes in the future that his store will grow to a bigger one.

Washington needs the loan to purchase maize, beans, groundnuts and cassava for resale.

loans.use: To buy beans, maize, cassava and groundnuts for resale

loans.name: Jusper

texts.en:
Jusper O. M. is a 35-year-old married man with three children.  

He repairs electronic goods such as mobile phones to earn a living for his family. He gets a good number of customers in a day. Jusper has been operating the business for eleven years.  

Through Faulu Kenya, he has been able to buy tools for repairing electronic goods. He needs 50,000 KES to buy a mobile phone repair software kit.

loans.use: to buy a mobile phone repair software kit

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to purchase four sacks of charcoal and two sacks of rice.

loans.name: Fatuma

texts.en:
Fatuma A. lives in the Naguru neighbourhood in the city of Kampala, Uganda. She is married and has seven children, all of whom are in school.  She also takes care of additional family members (two orphans). Fatuma lives in a home that she owns. She has access to electricity and has access to piped water. Her major monthly expenses include food and school fees.   

Fatuma has a business of selling fruits and vegetables. She has been in this business for less than one year, and she works six days out of every week. Fatuma sells her products at the market, by means of retail. 

Fatuma has requested  a loan of 1,500,000 UGX from MCDT SACCO, which she will use to buy boxes of cabbages, passion fruits and yellow bananas.   

She also generates additional income through selling piped water.

The main business challenges for Fatuma include transportation and the rainy season.  

Her goals and aspirations for her business are to own a delivery van and also to educate her children up to university.

loans.use: To buy more boxes of cabbages, passion fruit and yellow bananas

loans.name: Kevina

texts.en:
Kevina is 43 years old and a single mother of five children living in Hioma, Uganda. She longs to educate her children up to university. 

She has a retail shop and has been running it for 15 years. Through her business, she has been able to build a house and pay school fees for her children. She is proud of the way business is moving. 

She faces a challenge of impassable roads to market places and in the future she hopes to diversify her business and sell fresh foods. 

Kevina needs the loan to buy salt, beans and cooking oil for resale.

loans.use: To purchase salt, beans and cooking oil for resale

loans.name: Joshua

texts.en: Joshua is 34 years old and married with two children. He runs Saina Agrovet where he sells animal drugs, animal feed and fertilizers. He has 4 years of experience in the business and has employed six people. He also does farming for extra income. He hopes to be a successful businessman in the future. He has requested 40,000 KES to buy animal feed.

loans.use: to buy animal feed

loans.name: Rezo

texts.en:
Rezo I. lives in the village of Buknari, Guria Region. He is 54 years old, married and lives with his wife and son. Omar, Rezo’s son, is 26 years old. He graduated from high school and now wants to continue learning and get a Master’s degree. Rezo’s family can’t afford Omar's studies, and they decided to get credit and expand their agricultural farm, to increase their income. 

Rezo has four milk cows and four calves. He sells 80 kg cheese per month. The cheese is sold in Chokhatauri (a nearby town). Along with the dairy farm, the family runs a bee-keeping business; they have 13 bee-hives and sell 250 kg honey per year. Also they have 300 nut trees and sell 500 kg nuts per year. 

With the requested loan, Rezo will purchase 8 additional bee-hives and wax plates. This will give them 150 kg additional honey per year. Taking into account the market price of the honey (8-10 Laris per kg) their annual income will increase by 1200 – 1500 Laris. 

As was mentioned above, the increase in the income will be used for financing the studies of Omar, Rezo’s son.

loans.use: to purchase bee-hives and wax-plates.

loans.name: Aidah

texts.en: Aidah is 42 years old, married and a mother of 6 children living in Hioma, Uganda. She has no other dependents and she is the soul breadwinner for her family. For 3 years she has been running a produce business, which she started with her savings. She faces challenges of competition and scarcity of food supplies. Her dream is to own a food store. Aidah needs a loan to buy maize flour to sell.

loans.use: to purchase maize

loans.name: Ghulam Fatima's Group

texts.en:
Ghulam Fatima lives in Pakpattan which is a small city in Punjab province, Pakistan, known for its agriculture industry. She owns a 2-room house there and lives in it with her family in the area of Shakar Gunj. 

Ghulam is a very supportive lady who sells bed-sheets to share the financial burden with her husband. She also does her household responsibilities very well and takes care of her children. She has given birth to four daughters. Two of them are studying while others are not of school-going age yet. 

She has applied for a loan from Kiva partner Asasah to improve her husband’s business selling fruits. He started this business 13 years ago. He operates his business in a busy market in the city and offers different seasonal fruit varieties to his customers. He has a good name in the market for his good customer dealings and reasonable rates.  Using the loan, he will put more variety of fresh seasonal fruit in his shop for resale. 

Ghulam is hopeful that the loan investment will take her husband’s business to a more profitable position which will help her family to live a better  life financially.

loans.use: To buy fresh seasonal fruit for fruit-selling business.

loans.name: Dinah

texts.en: Dinah is a 43-year-old, single mother of two. She operates a cafeteria where she has employed two people. She runs her business in a very competitive environment, hence she puts extra effort in her business to attract more customers. She hopes to grow her cafeteria to a resort in the future. She has requested 20,000 KES to buy beverages.

loans.use: to buy beverages for her cafeteria

loans.name: Harriet

texts.en: Harriet is married and has three children and one other dependent.  They live in their own house in Hioma, Uganda. Her family goal is to educate her children to attain a degree as minimum qualification. She operates a hardware shop and has been running it for nine years. She started by selling used clothes and then saved to start the shop after a long struggle.  Harriet faces a challenge of her customers defaulting on payments; her dream is to own at least four hardware shops in town. Harriet is requesting a loan to buy metals and iron sheets to sell.

loans.use: To purchase metals and iron sheets

loans.name: Getrude

texts.en: Getrude A. I. makes a living by operating a beauty salon in the Lucky Summer section of Nairobi. She has been in this business for three years and earns about KES. 10,000 a month. She is 29 years old, single and has a child who is 11 years old. This is her first loan from KADET LTD and she plans to use the entire amount to buy more beauty products, including facial creams, hair dyes and perfumes, to sell to her customers. The income she earns from this loan will allow her to pay her child's school fees. In the future, she hopes to expand her business by opening a larger and more modern beauty parlor.

loans.use: to buy beauty products to sell to her customers.

loans.name: John

texts.en: John has applied for this loan to buy hair-cutting machines for a salon that he has run for the last three years. He is 34 years old, married, has three children and lives in a two-room house in the town of Kyenjojo. He works hard because he dreams of building his own house someday and making enough money to provide all of his children with a good education.

loans.use: To buy hair-cutting machines for his salon

loans.name: Robina's Group

texts.en:
Robina belongs to Pakpattan which is a small city in Pakistan, known for its agriculture industry. She has been living there in the area of Shakar Gunj with her family for the past five years. She is 43 years old, married to M. A. who is involved in a scrap business. He provides scrap to different factories and to other scrap dealers on order. 

Robina supports her husband financially by doing sewing for her neighboring clients. She learnt this art before her marriage and earns good profits from her skills now every month.  She is the mother of two sons and two daughters. Her elder son works in a vegetable market as a vegetable vendor while her younger son works in a welding shop for a low income. Both of her daughters are getting an education. 

Robina has applied for a loan from Kiva partner Asasah for her husband who wants to buy scrap such as plastic bottles, used paper, etc. in bulk to fulfill the demands of his clients and to make more profits. 

Robina is hopeful that her husband who just started this business a year ago will be able to establish it with the help of a loan investment.

loans.use: To buy scrap for scrap business.

loans.name: Esther

texts.en: Esther is 25 years old, married and has a four-year-old child.  For the last three years, she has made a living by running a retail shop. She supplements her income by selling charcoal. Since joining Faulu Kenya, she has learned how to manage her finances and hopes someday to buy a piece of land. She has applied for a loan for 20,000 Kes to buy maize flour, cooking oil and rice to sell to her customers.

loans.use: To buy maize flour, cooking oil and rice to sell to her customers.

loans.name: John

texts.en: John is 33 years old, married and has one child. He also cares for four people who share the home he lives in. For the last five years he has run a shop in Kyenjojo where he sells various beverages, and is applying for this loan to buy a refrigerator to help keep some of his beverages cool. He dreams of providing his child with a good education.

loans.use: To buy a refrigerator for a shop that sells beverages.

loans.name: Thomas

texts.en: Thomas lives in Uganda, is 33 years old and is applying for this loan to buy items to sell in the clothing shop he runs in the town of Kyenjojo. It's important for him to buy new items now, because business in his shop always picks up before and during the Easter season. Thomas is married and has six children. He lives in a home which he shares with nine people who he also cares for, and dreams of buying land so that he can run a tea plantation and provide all of his children with a good education. His wife makes a living by running a hotel.

loans.use: To buy clothes to sell to his customers.

loans.name: Vicky

texts.en:
Vicky M. is a married woman with three children, all of whom attend school. She lives in a rental house that has electricity and piped water. Her greatest monthly expense is food for the family.

For the past three years, Vicky has sold meat goats to slaughterhouse owners. Her major challenge is the high cost of transportation in her business.

Vicky decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost her business. With her loan of 40,000 KES she wants to purchase five goats to resell. She dreams of expanding her business in the future.

loans.use: To purchase five goats to resell

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To buy yogurt and apples to sell in his store

loans.name: Zemfira

texts.en: Zemfira H. lives in Arpy with her husband. She works at the village hall as a staff secretary. She has a croft and is engaged in farming. She is also engaged in beekeeping and has thirty beehives. Her husband doesn’t work, so she wants to increase the number of beehives to get more income. With the requested loan she plans to purchase more beehives in order to get more income from selling honey. This will let Zemfira develop her beekeeping business and improve her living conditions.

loans.use: to buy more beehives

loans.name: Sari Kencana Group

texts.en:
Jro  Nyoman T. and all members of this group agreed to continue borrowing from MUK. Because Jro  Nyoman T. already has a local type of Bali sow,  this time her loan will be used to buy a superior piglet species with a price of Rp.350,000 per pig, which will be maintained for six months. She will buy 2 piglets.

Her husband, I Gusti Ketut Raka, strongly supports the work done by his wife, because it can help the family income.

 She has a hope that the business of pigs that has been undertaken will increase profitably. She also has a  dream that her children can continue their schooling to a higher level and have a better future.

loans.use: To buy  superior piglets.

loans.name: Josephine

texts.en:
Josephine K. N. is single and has ten children, four of whom are in school. She also takes care of her brother in law. She lives in the Nsooba Kyebando neighborhood in the city of Kampala, Uganda. Josephine lives in a home that she owns; she has access to electricity and piped water. Her major monthly expenses include food and school fees.

Josephine is a tailor. She has been in this business for eight years, and she works six days out of every week. Josephine sells her products from home. She also generates additional income through renting rooms. The main business challenges for Josephine include transportation and defaulters.

Josephine has requested a loan of 1,000,000 UGX from MCDT SACCO, which she will use to buy more rolls of material and and an overlock machine. Her goals and aspirations for her business are to own a tailoring school and also to build more rental rooms.

loans.use: To buy more rolls of material and an overlock machine

loans.name: Parvin

texts.ru: Parvin H. 22 qoda. Ona ne zamujem i ne imeyet detey. Parvin jivet v Avbsehron regione vmeste so svoimi roditelyami, ona pomoqayet svoyey semye. Parvin Uje 2 qoda kak zanimayetsya vipechkoy sladostey, imeyet svoyu malenkuyu pekarnu. Seychas ona nujdayetsya v 2300 AZN chtobi kupit novuyu pechku dlya vipechki sladostey.
texts.en: Parvin H. is 22 years old.  She is single and childless.  Parvin lives in Absheron with her parents.  She helps her family.  For the last two years, Parvin has been baking sweets.  She has her own bakery.  Now, she needs 2300 AZN to buy a new oven for baking sweets.

loans.use: to buy a new oven for baking

loans.name: Poulyne Kwamboka

texts.en:
Poulyne Kwamboka N. is married to Peterson, and they have one child. She has a boutique in Lucky Summer estate in Nairobi. She has been in this business for two years and earns an income of 10,000 KES monthly.

Poulyne learned about KADET LTD through a friend. She is applying for her first loan with which she plans to purchase more stocks of cosmetics, bags and beauty products to sell. She plans to use the anticipated income to pay school fees for her child.

Poulyne hopes to expand her business and deal in a variety of beauty products. She hopes to grow her business to give her children a better education.

loans.use: To purchase cosmetics, bags and beauty products to resell

loans.name: Florence

texts.en:
Florence is a twenty-seven-year-old single mother with one child. She rents a house in Kasese. Florence has been dealing in fresh foods for three years, a business she started with 300,000 UGX. She now has 800,000 UGX. Her problem is high transport costs.

Florence intends to use her profits to buy additional fresh foods. Her vision is to build a house and set up a food store.

loans.use: To buy fresh foods

loans.name: Jennifer

texts.en:
Jennifer C., a 25-year-old married mother of two children who are still young, lives with her family in Waunifor, located on the outskirts of Eldoret. Her husband, Isaac Bitok, runs a retail business that contributes to the family's income, while Jennifer is a maize farmer who earns a monthly income of KES. 15,000.

Having repaid her previous loans, Jennifer is now requesting a new one from KADET LTD in order to buy maize seedlings and fertilizer. With the additional income that will arise from the loan, she plans to buy another piece of land to expand her farming business. In the future she wants to educate her children and buy a pick-up truck to more easily transport maize to her customers.

loans.use: to buy maize seedlings and fertilizer

loans.name: Tatu

texts.en:
Tatu M. is a divorced woman with six children, all of whom attend school. She lives in her own house that has neither electricity nor piped water. Her greatest monthly expense is school fees.

Tatu has operated a food stall for the past three years, selling to her neighbors and passersby. She cooks chapatti (flat bread), beans and rice for sale. Tatu has been able to provide for her children’s basic needs and education from her earnings.

Tatu decided to join Yehu to access funds to boost her business. With a loan of 20,000 KES she wants to purchase bundles of maize flour, wheat flour and sacks of beans.

loans.use: To purchase bundles of maize flour, wheat flour and sacks of beans

loans.name: Tigran

texts.en: Tigran G. lives in Sisian, Armenia. He is engaged in agriculture. He gets his main income from selling milk. Tigran has applied to SEF for a loan  to increase the livestock. With the requested loan he plans to buy calves and get more income from selling calves and milk. With the profits,Tigran hopes to be able to repair his house and to get married.

loans.use: to pay for livestock

loans.name: Dinah

texts.en:
Dinah, 42, is married and has five children. She owns a house in Kasese, Uganda.

Dinah has been in the bar and hotel business for eleven years, and it’s still booming. Her problem is drunk customers who break her glasses.

Dinah wants a loan to buy seats and more drinks to sell. Her vision is to move to a bigger bar, build a house and educate her children.

loans.use: To buy seats and more drinks to sell

loans.name: Gladys

texts.en:
Gladys, 35, is married and has four children. She owns a house in Kasese, Uganda. She has been selling coffee for three years and with the proceeds she has been able to pay school fees for her children.

Gladys’ problem is the low quality of coffee she sells that thus fetches a low income. She needs a loan to buy better coffee. Gladys’ goal is to sell high-quality coffee.

loans.use: To buy a higher-grade coffee to sell

loans.name: Venaline

texts.en:
Venaline J. is a young woman of twenty-five years, married and a mother of two children. The family lives in Waunifor in the outskirts of Eldoret town. Venaline has been a maize farmer for the past four years. She makes a monthly income of 5,000 KES.

This will be Venaline's second loan from KADET LTD. She successfully repaid her first loan, and with this loan she plans to buy maize seedlings and fertilizer for her farm. With the income that she hopes to get, she plans to buy a dairy cow.

In the future Venaline wants to buy another piece of land, educate her children and invest more in dairy farming.

loans.use: To buy maize seedings and fertilizer

loans.name: Janet

texts.en:
Janet, forty, is married with six children. She owns a house in Kasese, Uganda.

Janet has been dealing in produce for twenty years. She started with 200,000 UGX and now has three million UGX. She is requesting a loan to buy more maize and beans to sell. Her problem is high employee turnover.

In the future she intends to set up her own food store.

loans.use: To buy more maize and beans to sell.

loans.name: Gorette

texts.en:
Gorette is  47 and is married with five children, ages 14 through 24 years old. She also takes care of two relatives ages 12 and 16 years old. Only Gorette works in her family. She runs a hand crafts  business. She has been in this business for three years and her hours of operation are from 7am until 6pm daily.

Gorette has requested this loan through Vision Finance Company in order to expand her business by buying more hand crafts. The extra income generated from this loan will help her to save for the future.

loans.use: To purchase more hand crafts.

loans.name: Josephine

texts.en: Josephine is currently in the business of selling sweet potatoes. She is 45 years old, married, and has 7 children who all go to school. Josephine borrowed a loan to stock more sweet potatoes to sell. She hopes to build a house with the extra profits from her business in the future.

loans.use: to stock more sweet potatoes to sell.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy beans and firewood to sell.

loans.name: Henry

texts.en:
Henry K. A. is 36 years old, married, and a father of three beautiful children. He lives in Tuiyo, in the outskirts of Eldoret. His wife Esther has a horticulture business in the same area and adds to the family's income. Henry buys and sells livestock and also sells milk from his dairy cows to his customers. 


He has been in this business for ten years now and gets a monthly income of twenty thousand shillings.This will be Henry's second loan from KADET LTD, he plans to use the entire money to buy more cows for sale. 

The income he is going to get he will  buy dairy cows so that he can increase his milk production for sale. In future he wants to diversify his business and start a butchery business in Eldoret town, he also wants to educate his children.

loans.use: to buy more cows for sale

loans.name: Denis

texts.en: Denis is a twenty-eight year old hard working man and he rents a house in Kasese, Uganda. He has been dealing in passion fruits for ten years. He started with a capital of 200,000 shillings and now has 900,000 shilling as working capital. His hardship is changes in market prices and his vision is having an orchard and having a family.

loans.use: to buy bags of passion fruits to sell.

loans.name: Vepkhia

texts.en:
Vepkhia T. comes from Japana, a small village in the Guria Region. He is 44 years old, married and lives with his wife Tamar, nine- and 10-year-old sons and his mother. Agriculture is the only source of income for the family. 

Vepkhia and Tamar run a small dairy farm with six milk cows and sell approximately 100 kg of traditional Georgian cheese per month in a nearby town. Also the family owns a 1.5 ha plot of land where vegetables, maize, and watermelon are grown. Harvested grain, fruits and vegetables are sold locally to wholesalers. From all the above-mentioned activities the family earns approximately 650 Laris per month.

With the requested credit Vepkhia plans to purchase fertilizers, watermelon seeds, and cultivate the land. 

The income received from watermelon sales will be used for the renovation of their house.

loans.use: to purchase fertilizers, watermelon seeds, and cultivate the land.

loans.name: Rehema

texts.en:
Rehema is a single woman who lives at her own house that has electricity and piped water. Her greatest monthly expenses are food and clothing. For the past three months, Rehema has been selling fruit as retail to her neighbours and passersby. In addition, she also operates a Khanga business (traditional African women's attire), selling them as wholesale which contributes to her other source of income.

Rehema dreams of expanding her business in the future. With the Kshs 30,000 she is requesting she wants to purchase five sacks of fruit for resale. She decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost her business.

loans.use: to purchase five sacks of fruit for resale.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to purchase medicines to resell

loans.name: Smbat

texts.en: Smbat S. lives in the village Shaqe, in the Syunik region of Armenia with his pensioner mother and 2 sons. He works as a driver, but the salary is too low to meet the family needs. So Smbat is also engaged in agriculture. He needs more financial means to develop  agriculture business. With the requested loan Smbat plans to buy seeds and fuel.

loans.use: to pay for seeds and fuel

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy maize, beans and peas

loans.name: Susan

texts.en:
Susan is a farmer in her hometown of Nkubu in Central Kenya. She is married with four children aged between 3 to 10 years with the first two already attending school. She has been in the mixed farming business for 15 years producing maize, beans, eggs, milk and tea, which are all sold locally.

Susan has made a request for a loan amounting to 60,000 KES from Juhudi Kilimo to enable her expand her poultry business though the purchase of more birds. She says the expansion of the poultry business will make her realize more income and adequately provide for her young family. She aspires to grow her farm in future though purchase of additional land.

Susan laments that disease outbreaks and low market prices are the main challenges to farming businesses in the area. She adds that Juhudi Kilimo loans have really helped needy families.

loans.use: to purchase poultry for resale

loans.name: Emily

texts.en:
Emily J. R. is 38 years old, married, and a mother of six children. They live in Waunifor in the outskirts of Eldoret. Emily is a maize farmer, and she sells the produce after harvest and has been in this business for eighteen years now. She gets a monthly income of thirty thousand shillings, and she also runs a retail shop in the same area, while her husband is also a maize farmer.

This will be Emily's third loan from KADET LTD. She repaid all other loans successfully, and she plans to use the entire loan on the farm by buying maize seedlings and fertilizer. With the income she is going to get from selling the maize, she wants to stock her shop with the money. In future she wants to educate her children to the highest level and also buy another piece of land.

loans.use: to buy maize, seedlings and fertilizer

loans.name: Ruth

texts.en:
Ruth J. M. is a lady of thirty-three years, married and a mother of three children. They live in Waunifor in the outskirts of Eldoret town. Her husband, Hillary Sirma, works with the Kenya police and brings in income to the family. Ruth does maize farming and has been in this business for eleven years, and she gets a monthly income of three thousand shillings.

This will be Ruth's third loan from KADET LTD, and with this loan she plans to buy maize seedlings and fertilizer for her farm. The income that she will get from selling the maize will be used to buy another piece of land. 

In future she wants to buy twenty acres of land, educate her children and buy vehicles for transporting her produce to her customers.

loans.use: to buy maize seedlings and fertilizer

loans.name: Sejerina

texts.en: P. is currently in the business of selling tea. She is 38 years old, married, with one child who does not go to school. P. borrowed a loan to stock more tea to sell. She hopes to open a big shop in the future with extra profits from her business.

loans.use: stock more tea to sell

loans.name: Asia's Group

texts.en:
Asia is a housewife who stays at home and does her household responsibilities. She is very helpful by nature and always ready to support her family in their time of need. She has given birth to three children. All of them are very young and have not started getting an education yet. Her husband’s name is M. A. and he sells vegetables in the vegetable market. He is well known for his good customer dealings and the quality of his vegetables.
 
Asia has applied for a loan from Kiva partner Asasah to further improve her husband’s vegetable-selling business. Using the loan, he will buy fresh seasonal vegetables to sell to his customers. He has been operating this business for the past five years and Asia is hopeful that through the loan investment, her husband will successfully be able to increase his sales and profits. She is a new loan user and hopes that it will bring good profits to her husband as a result. 

She belongs to a city called Pakpattan which is a small city in Punjab, Pakistan, known for its agriculture. She owns a two-room brick house there and has been living in it with her family for the past 15 years. 

Note: In the photo, the lady raising her hand is Asia.

loans.use: To buy fresh seasonal vegetables for vegetable-selling business.

loans.name: Samson

texts.en:
Samson K. K. is 27 years old, married to Vivian, and they have one child. He does maize farming in Mosop in Eldoret, plus he does has a retail shop in the same area, and he has been doing this business for eleven years now. He gets a monthly income of ten thousand shillings.

This will be Samson's fourth loan from KADET LTD. He has repaid all other loan successfully, and he plans to use the entire loan to buy farm inputs like maize seeds and fertilizer. With the income that he is going to get from sale of maize he will use the money to buy stock for his retail shop.

In future he wants to continue with farming and also educate his child.

loans.use: to buy maize seeds and fertilizers for the farm

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to purchase a dairy cow

loans.name: Jane

texts.en:
Jane J. M. is 41 years old, married and a mother of three children, and they live in Waunifor in the outskirts of Eldoret town. Her husband is a driver, and Jane does maize farming and has been in this business for sixteen years. She gets a monthly income of KES. 5,000.

This will be Jane's second loan from KADET LTD, and she wants to use the entire loan to buy maize seedlings and fertilizer. The income that she will get will be used to pay school fees for her children. 

In future Jane wants to educate her children further and also buy a plot in Eldoret town.

loans.use: to buy maize seedlings and  fertilizer

loans.name: David

texts.en:
David K. G. is 54 years old. He is married to Edith Njoki and they have three children together. He runs a mini petro station and has been in this business for the last five years.

This marks David’s first loan from KADET, and he plans to purchase more diesel to put into his business. The income that will be generated from the business will be directed into the expansion of the business.

His dream is to venture into the transport sector.

loans.use: purchase more diesel for his petro station

loans.name: Damaris

texts.en:
Damaris is a married woman with six children, four of whom still attend school. She owns a house that has electricity and piped water. Her greatest monthly expense is school fees. She has operated a firewood-selling business for the past year, selling from home to her neighbouring community members. 

Damaris experiences a challenge of the high cost of transporting charcoal from rural areas to her place of operation. She dreams of establishing a retail shop in the future.

With the Kshs 40,000 she is requesting, she wants to purchase bundles of firewood for resale. She decided to work with Yehu to access loans to boost her business.

loans.use: to purchase bundles of firewood for resale

loans.name: Nazeeran's Group

texts.en:
Nazeeran is 57 years old and still very active. She stays at home and does her household responsibilities. She makes the utmost effort to bring comfort to her family by fulfilling their needs. She is a widow and lives with her five children in Pakpattan, which is a small city located in Punjab, Pakistan, known for its agricultural industry. Her home contains two rooms made of bricks and is situated in the area of Karam Pura. She moved there 15 years ago. 

Due to the death of her husband and her poor financial conditions, Nazeeran couldn’t provide education to her sons and they had to start work to earn income for the family. Her eldest son is a tailor and runs a tailoring shop in the market. The second one works in a Punjabi food restaurant and the youngest one works in an electronics shop as a salesman. Both of her daughters are studying. 

Nazeeran has applied for a loan from Kiva's partner, Asasah, for her eldest son who wants to buy a new sewing machine to improve his tailoring business. The new machine will help him fulfill larger orders on time and earn better profits. He has five years of experience in his business and Nazeeran is hopeful that he will be able to improve his business after investing this loan in it.

loans.use: to buy a new sewing machine for a tailoring business.

loans.name: Martun

texts.en: Martun T. lives in the village of Gorayk, in the Syunik region of Armenia. He keeps livestock. Martun wants to get engaged in farming but he doesn’t have enough financial means. He had already applied to SEF before. Now he wants to apply again to get a loan for buying seeds. Now Martun will develop agriculture and he will be able to meet his family’s needs.

loans.use: to pay for seeds

loans.name: Perveen's Group

texts.en:
Perveen is married to M. A. and lives in Pakpattan, Pakistan, which is famous for its agricultural industry. Her house is located in Karampura which is a small residential area of the city. She moved there 20 years ago. Her husband works for a private organization with a reasonable income. Perveen has given birth to four sons and a daughter. Her two elder sons left their education and started work to financially support the family. Her eldest son sells cooking oil while the second one is a rickshaw driver and provides transport services to passengers. Her remaining children are enrolled in a local school and are getting their education. 

Perveen has applied for a loan from Kiva's partner, Asasah, for her second son who wants to repair his rickshaw because it has gone rough and needs urgent repairing. Perveen is hopeful that, after repairing the rickshaw, her son will be able to provide better transport services to his passengers and make more profits. He has been in his business for the past 10 years.

In the photo, the lady with a raised hand is Perveen.

loans.use: to repair a rickshaw.

loans.name: Leonid

texts.en:
Leonid is married with two grown children. He is a farmer from Kamenka. Leonid grows early spring vegetables, mostly tomatoes. He owns 17 big greenhouses and 2 separate ones for seedlings. Leonid has been in this farming business for 25 years. He has invested about 300,000 Grivnyas into it.  

Leonid is seeking a loan of 17,000 Grivnyas to purchase fertilizers for his 17 greenhouses. He is hoping to increase the quality and amounts of harvested vegetables this farming season.  Better fertilizers will ensure better and richer crops, thus guaranteeing stable income for Leonid and his family.

loans.use: to purchase fertilizers for his greenhouses

loans.name: Mapendo Group

texts.fr: Mwanaidi K. est leader du groupe d’affaire Mapendo, elle lève la main sur la photo, cliente au 15e  cycle de crédit,âgée de 43 ans,divorcée. Elle est mère de 10 enfants parmi lesquels 6 vont à l’école et d’autres ont leurs propres foyers.Notons qu’elle supporte seule la charge de ses enfants car son ancien mari l’a complètement abandonné. Elle a commencé ses activités avec un capital de son mari avant qu’ils divorcent.  Son Busines est de fournir les poulets aux hôtels,snack bars, restaurants de la ville,etc. Il y a 24 ans qu’elle exerce cette activité de vente des poulets. Avec ce nouveau crédit, elle souhaite augmenter son chiffre d’affaire en achetant 50 poulets. Dans l’avenir, elle planifie diversifier  ses activités et acheter un véhicule de transports. Mwanaidi K. remercie l’IMF Hekima pour les crédits qu’elle reçoit sans aucune garantie matérielle car grâce à ces crédits elle parvient à subvenir aux besoins de ses enfants. Le groupe  Mapendo est  composé des 19 membres majoritairement femmes.
texts.en:
Mwanaidi K. (raising her hand in the picture) is the leader of the Mapendo group and she's seeking her fifteenth loan. She's 43 years old, divorced, and the mother of ten children, of whom six attend school while others live on their own). It must be noted that she has to support her children by herself, since her former husband abandoned her completely.

She started her business with a capital obtained from her husband, before their divorce. Her business, which she has been running for 24 years, consists in providing chickens to hotels, snack bars, restaurants… of the city. With this new loan, she wishes to bolster her revenue by purchasing 50 chickens. In the future, she intends to diversify her business and purchase a transport vehicle.

Mwanaidi K. thanks Kiva's partner, MFI Hekima, for the loans she receives with no collateral at all. Thanks to these loans, she manages to provide for her children. Mapendo group is composed of 19 members, mostly women.

loans.use: to buy 50 chickens

location.country: The Democratic Republic of the Congo

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to purchase sugar, flour, rice, soft drinks, cooking oil, toothpaste, and bread

loans.name: Linah

texts.en:
Linah is a single mother of one child who attends school. She owns a house that neither has electricity nor piped water. Her greatest monthly expenses are food and school fees. For the past eight years, she has operated a french fries-selling business, and she sells from home to her neighbours and passersby. In addition she also sells fish and firewood to her neighbours, which contributed as her other source of income. 

With the Kshs 40,000 she is requesting she wants to purchase sacks of potatoes, cooking oil and fish for resale. She decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost her business.

loans.use: to purchase sacks of potatoes, cooking oil and fish for sale

loans.name: Sergei

texts.en:
Sergei is a private businessman from Novomoskovsk. He owns a vending location in the local marketplace called Slavyanskyi. Sergei sells sportswear items. His vending facility is known for the best assortment of merchandise among other market vendors working with similar type of inventory. Sergei has been in this business for over 5 years. Presently, he has about 50,000 Grivnyas in inventory. 

Sergei is seeking a 20,000 Grivnya loan to purchase caps and sweatsuits to diversify his merchandise this spring season. He is hoping to continue growing his business and generate stable income this summer to be invested in a purchase of a vending facility in fall. His business is the only source of income for the family.

loans.use: to purchase caps and seasonal sportswear to resell

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to purchase a sewing machine and cloth materials

loans.name: Razia's Group

texts.en:
Razia lives in a small city of Punjab, Pakistan, called Kasur. It is well known for its tanneries industry. Her home consists of two rooms and is made of bricks. Her husband’s name is J. I. and he is involved in a dairy business. He keeps some goats and a buffalo at home. He gets up early in the morning and gets milk from the cattle to sell in the community to earn good profits. 

Razia herself is a housewife. She stays at home and does her household responsibilities. In her spare time, she also takes care of the cattle by providing them with timely food and water. She has given birth to six children. Her eldest son is a daily wage labor while one daughter does embroidery work for clients in the community. The remaining children are getting their education and studying in different classes. 

Razia has applied for a loan from Kiva's partner, Asasah, to buy another buffalo which will help her husband increase milk productivity and sales. Her husband has been operating his business for the past three years and Razia is hopeful that an investment will help him provide better financial facilities for the family as a result. She is a new loan user and this is her first loan application to Asasah.

loans.use: to buy another buffalo for a dairy business.

loans.name: Namatovu

texts.en:
Namatovu O. M. is 30 years old. She is married to David Wanyonyi and they have been blessed with two children. Namatovu O. runs a food kiosk back in Bamburi, and she has been in this business for the last two years.

This marks her second loan from KADET, and she plans to renovate the business premise. The anticipated income will be directed into the repayment of the loan. Her hopes and dreams are to improve her living standards.

loans.use: to renovate and expand her business premise

loans.name: Natalya

texts.en:
Natalya is a widow with a grown son. She is a market entrepreneur from Novomoskovsk. Natalya sells extra-size coats, jackets, and costumes for women in the local market called Slavyanskyi. Natalya has a good experience working with this type of merchandise. She started the business over 7 years ago. She has invested about 80,000 Grivnyas in her venture. Prior to launching the business Natalya worked in a clothing designer’s workshop. 

Natalya is requesting a loan of 20,000 Grivnyas to purchase women’s raincoats and jackets for the chilly spring season in Ukraine. She is planning to continue developing her trade, increasing her income and living conditions as a result. Natalya became a widow last year. However, she didn’t give up and managed to move on and put up with the loss of her husband.

loans.use: to purchase women’s jackets and raincoats for spring season

loans.name: Altantsetseg

texts.en:
Altantsetseg is 41 years old and lives with her husband and only daughter in a house in Songinohairhan district, Ulaanbaatar, the capital city of Mongolia. Her husband, age 56, is a retired man and her daughter is a student. She manages a taxi service business in Ulaanbaatar city. She started her business in 2007. 

Since then she has been able to stabilize her business and is planning to continue her business in the future. Now her monthly net profit is 330,000 MNT with daily earning of 30,000 MNT. Her husband is very supportive with her business and provides much advice on how to improve her service. Altantsetseg herself is a very hardworking and honest woman who provides safe and comfortable service to her customers. She says. "I am thankful to Xacbank for trusting me and lending me some money which helped me to improve my business." She is requesting a 2,000,000 MNT of loan to purchase some construction materials to fix her house.

loans.use: to purchase some construction materials

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to purchase and insure a dairy cow

loans.name: Naranchimeg

texts.en:
Naranchimeg is 45 years old and lives with her husband and two children in a house in Songinohairhan district, Ulaanbaatar, the capital city of Mongolia. Her older son, age 20, goes to a college and younger daughter, age 15, attends a local secondary school.

She operates a traditional clothing making business with the help of her husband in Ulaabaatar city. She started her business in 1998. She is responsible for making traditional clothing called Deel, and her husband is responsible for selling them at a rented stall at a trading center. Her business is quite profitable, which allowed her to buy a car last year. Now, her monthly net profit is 650,000 MNT, with a daily earning of 80,000 MNT. She makes two pairs of Deel per day at a cost of 40,000 MNT and sells them for 80,000 MNT. She has gained a lot of experience and is planning to expand her business in the future. She is an honest woman who says, “I make traditional clothes that satisfy my customer's need." She is requesting a 1,200,000 MNT of loan to purchase materials for her business.

loans.use: to purchase sewing materials

loans.name: Ludmila

texts.en:
Ludmila is married with grown children. She lives in Novomoskovsk. Ludmila sells women’s clothing items in one of the local markets called ‘Slavyanskyi’, i.e. dresses, skirts, blouses, etc. Ludmila’s vending facility can boast a favorable location at the marketplace which only adds to the success of her business. She has loyal clientele who trust her taste and choice of fashionable clothing inventory.  

Ludmila has been in this business for over 6 years. She has invested about 50,000 Grivnyas in inventory. Currently, Ludmila is seeking a loan of 20,000 Grivnyas to purchase a variety of trendy women’s clothing and classic dresses for spring/summer season. She has already placed her order with a wholesaler and presently only needs to pay for it. Ludmila can be characterized as entrepreneurial and optimistic which has been instrumental on her road to success in business.

loans.use: to purchase a variety of women’s clothing and dresses

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: To buy cotton clothes and slippers at wholesale to add to her business

loans.name: Sainbayar

texts.en:
Sainbayar is 51 years old and lives with his wife and son in their own house in Songinohairhan district, Ulaanbaatar, the capital city of Mongolia. His son is a student. He operates an auto parts sales business with the help of his wife, at a rented stall at a local market called Uguumur. He started his business in 1995. At first he used to sell his goods at an outdoor market. After years of business operation, he gained experience and managed to rent a stall at an indoor market. Also, he established a good relationship both with his customers and partners.

Now his monthly net profit is 400,000-500,000 MNT, with a daily earning of 100,000 MNT. He buys used, old cars and makes them into small parts which are ready to be sold. He is an honest man who says, "I am planning to open my own auto repair shop in the future." He is requesting a 3,000,000 MNT loan to purchase more spare parts for his business.

loans.use: to purchase more spare parts

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to purchase two bundles of wheat flour and one sack of beans.

loans.name: Road To Success Group

texts.en:
Mohamed K. is the leader of this group of entrepreneurs. Mohamed was born in a village called Malal about 45 years ago. He is married to a trader and the couple has 3 children who are attending primary and secondary schools. Mohamed sells bags – ladies bags, school bags, office bags, etc.  He has been managing this type of business for 10 years now. 

With the help of this loan, Mohamed and his group member will be able to expand their businesses, make more sales and consequently improve their living conditions. Mohamed will use his share of the loan (SLL 1,200,000) to buy different types of bags in larger quantity to add to his current stock.

loans.use: to buy different types of bags in larger quantity

loans.name: Togoohuu

texts.en:
Togoohuu is 34 years old and lives with her husband and two children in a house in Songinohairhan district, Ulaanbaatar, capital city of Mongolia. Her  son is a student and her daughter hasn't reached school age yet. 

Togoohuu manages a construction materials business with the help of her husband at a trading center. She started her business in 2005. Since then her business has been quite profitable and she has been able to stabilize her business. Now her monthly sales have reached 7,000,000 MNT.  She imports her goods from Ereen, a border city of China. She is planning to expand and continue her business in the future. She is an honest women who attributes her business success to good communication skills. She says, "I want to complete construction work on my house and live as comfortably as I can." She is requesting a 3,000,000 MNT loan to purchase more construction materials for her business.

loans.use: to purchase more construction materials

loans.name: Peter

texts.en: Peter is 28 years old, married, and blessed with one child.  He runs a boda boda (motorbike) transport business.  He was previously working as a driver.  Being a member of Faulu Kenya, he has been trained in business record keeping.  This has helped him to run his business well.  He hopes to build apartments within five years.  He has requested  70,000 Kes to buy a motorbike.

loans.use: to buy a motorbike

loans.name: Talapsu Group

texts.en:
Marie C. is the leader of this group of entrepreneurs. Marie was born in a place call Punthu, about 37 years ago. She is married to a teacher and the couple has 5 children, 3 of whom attend primary and secondary schools. 

For 15 years now, Marie has been selling sugar, kerosene, fire-wood, etc.  With the help of this loan, Marie and her group members will be able to expand their businesses, make more sales and profit and consequently improve their living conditions. Marie will use her share of the loan to buy the above mentioned items in bulk to add to her current ones.

loans.use: to buy sugar, kerosene, fire-wood, etc., in bulk

loans.name: Mano Group

texts.en:
In the photo are members of the “Mano” group. They are small-scale businesspeople based in Makeni, a city in northern Sierra Leone. They have come to SMT/Kiva lenders to request a loan of SLL 1,400,000 for each, in order to improve their businesses. The leader of this group is Dura S.. 

Dura is 59 years old.   He was born in Makeni city, where he is currently residing with his wife and 3 children. His wife is a businesswoman and 2 of his children are attending primary school.  One is in secondary school.  Dura has been selling fowl for many years now.  He will use his share of this loan to buy dozens of fowl to resell.

loans.use: to buy dozens of fowl

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to purchase fowl

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: to buy cigarettes, body creams, mattresses, palm-oil, rice, soap, toothpaste, etc. in larger quantities

loans.name: Khatuna

texts.en:
Khatuna S. lives in Akhali Sopeli (“New Village”) in Imereti Region. She is 31 years old and married. Khatuna and her husband, Vaja, have two children: a 13-year-old daughter and a 12-year-old son, who go to the local secondary school. The income of the family comes from their small agricultural farm, where Khatuna and Vaja work hard during the whole day. In particular, the family has three milk cows. The milk is used to make cheese – 60 kg per month is sold in a nearby town. They have two pigs, whose piglets are sold locally. In their 500 sq. meter greenhouse, Khatuna and Vaja grow cucumbers – approximately 3 tones of cucumbers are sold annually. Also, the family uses their plot of land to grow maize. Most of the harvested corn is used for the farm, to feed the pigs and piglets. The total average monthly profit from all the above mentioned activities amounts to 800 laris per month.

The requested funding will be used to replace the old damaged cellophane in the greenhouse with a new one, as well as for fertilizing the ground there. After fertilizing and installing new cellophane, the harvest of cucumbers and the income from their sales will increase by 25%. Another part of the loan will be used for cultivation of the land, where maize will be sown. It will increase the harvest and sale of corn by 50%. 

The increase in their income will be used for renovations to their house, in order to improve the living conditions for the family members.

loans.use: to purchase cellophane, fertilizers and fuel for the tractor.

loans.name: Bah

texts.fr:
BAH B. est âgée de 63 ans,  veuve et mère de 9 enfants, elle vit dans une famille nucléaire  avec ses enfants au quartier Darsalam de Ségou  (quatrième région administrative de la république du Mali).
 N’ayant pas fréquenté l’école pour des raisons sociales, elle commença tôt à faire le commerce d’articles divers tels l’atieké, les balaies et autres marchandises venant de la  côte d’ivoire. Elle mène cette activité depuis plus de 35 ans et jouit d’une grande clientèle et notoriété. Sa force de vente est due à son prix abordable : il y a toujours une marge de 100 FCFA entre ses prix et ceux des autres vendeuses.
Dans  le but d’augmenter son fonds de commerce afin de faire face à la demande clientèle, elle a fait recours à Soro Yiriwaso. Elle est en relation avec cette dernière depuis 54 mois,  après 3 prêts solidaires et 3 prêts individuels tous  bien remboursés, elle  est à son 4ème   prêt individuel et compte l’utiliser pour acheter 1,5 tonne d’atieké. Elle s’approvisionne à Abidjan. Madame BAH B.  vend au comptant et à crédit à une clientèle composée généralement de femmes. Elle compte réaliser un bénéfice mensuel de 75 000 FCFA, qui lui permettra  de rembourser son prêt et à aider ses enfants dans la prise en charge des dépenses familiales.
texts.en:
BAH B., age 63, is a widow and the mother of nine children. She lives in a nuclear family with her children in the Darsalam quarter in Ségou (fourth administrative region of the Republic of Mali). Never having attended school on account of social reasons, she started early on to sell various products such as "atieké" (a couscous-like dish made with cassava), brooms, and other items imported from Ivory Coast.

She's been running this business for more than 35 years, and has acquired a large clientele and a good reputation. Her strength is her affordable pricing : she's always XOF 100 (ca US$ 0.20) less expensive than other sellers. In order to bolster her working capital and meet customer demand, she turns to  Kiva's partner, Soro Yiriwaso. She's been a customer for 54 months, and after 3 individual and 3 group loans, she's now seeking her fourth loan.

She intends to use it to buy one ton of atieké. She gets her supplies in Abidjan and resells for cash and on credit, to a clientele comprising mostly women. She intends to turn a monthly profit of XOF 75'000 (ca US$ 160), which will enable her to repay the loan and help her children by taking part in the daily expenses of the family.

loans.use: to buy one ton of "atieké" (a couscous-like dish made with cassava)

loans.name: Peter

texts.en: Peter is a member of Faulu Kenya under a group.  He joined Faulu Kenya as a businessman who runs a retail shop.  Being a member of Faulu Kenya, he is able to save his money with the group, share business ideas, and access loans easily because the members of the group guarantee each other's loans.  He has employed two people in his business.  Apart from running a retail shop, he operates a van (matatu) transport business.  He hopes to open a supermarket in the future.  He has requested  80,000 Kes to install a kerosene pump.

loans.use: to install kerosene pump

loans.name: John U.'s Group

texts.en:
Salone Microfinance Trust (SMT), a partner of Kiva.org in Makeni, northern Sierra Leone, is pleased to present to you teachers of the RC Primary School, Kagomgbeh village, near Makeni city.  RC Primary School, Kagomgbeh, was founded in 1980 by the Roman Catholic Mission to meet the educational needs of the children of Kagomgbeh village. RC Primary School has a staff of 7 teachers and an enrollment of 221 pupils. This school is the only school in the community. 

School staff came to SMT to apply for loans so that they could accomplish certain tasks that they would otherwise not have been able to accomplish with salaries alone. But with the help of this loan, some can pay school fees for their children; others can use the loan to buy pieces of furniture, a plot of land, house-building materials, or invest in business. At the end of each month, these teachers can repay the loan out of their monthly salaries. The institution’s bursar is directly responsible for deducting the repayment and pays SMT on their behalf.

John U. S. is the head teacher at the school and leader of this group. The 47 year-old John was born in Binkolo village, about 7 miles from Makeni. He has been in the teaching profession for 26 years now. He is married to a fish seller, and the couple has 5 children – 3 in primary school, 1 in secondary school and the other not yet of school age.  Mr S. has requested this loan in order to complete building his house. He will use the loan to buy bags of cement, paints, nails, etc.  

(Attached in the right side corner of the group photo is a group member who was not able to be present for a group shot).

loans.use: to buy bags of cement, paints, nails, etc.

loans.name: Assitan Cheick

texts.fr:
Madame ASSITAN CHEICK D. est âgée de 26 ans,  célibataire et mère de 1 enfant. Elle vit dans une famille nucléaire  avec  sa mère et ses frères  au quartier Missira de Ségou  (quatrième région administrative de la république du Mali).
Ayant abandonnée l’école en classe de 9ème année fondamentale (système éducatif Malien), elle commença à faire le commerce de draps de lits auprès de sa mère. Après plusieurs années d’apprentissage à ses cotés, elle évolue seule, en menant la même activité et cela depuis maintenant 5 ans et jouit d’une grande clientèle. 
Dans  le but d’augmenter son fonds de commerce afin de faire face à la demande clientèle, elle a fait recours à Soro Yiriwaso. Elle est  à son 1er    prêt individuel et compte l’utiliser pour acheter 2 rouleaux de draps. Elle s’approvisionne à Bobo au Burkina Faso. 
Madame  ASSITAN CHEICK D.  vend au comptant et à crédit à une clientèle composée  de femmes majoritairement. Elle compte réaliser un bénéfice mensuel de 50 000 FCFA, qui lui servira à rembourser son prêt et à   se prendre soi même  en charge (achat de vêtements et de cosmétiques). 
Son ambition est de donner plus d’élan à son activité.
texts.en:
Mrs. ASSITAN CHEICK D., age 26, is single and the mother of one child. She lives in a nuclear family with her mother and brothers in Missira, a neighborhood in Ségou (fourth administrative region of the Republic of Mali). Having dropped out of school after the ninth year, she started selling bed sheets with her mother and spent several years training beside her. She's now been working on her own for five years, and has acquired a large clientele.

In order to bolster her working capital and meet customer demand, she turned to Kiva's partner, Soro Yiriwaso. She's seeking her first personal loan, and intends to use it to buy two rolls of bed sheets. She gets her supplies in Bobo in Burkina Faso.

Mrs. ASSITAN CHEICK D. sells for cash and on credit, to a clientele comprising mostly women. She intends to turn a monthly profit of XOF 50'000 (cas US$ 110), to be used to repay the loan and provide for herself (clothing and cosmetics). She ambitions to bolster her business.

loans.use: to buy two rolls of bed sheets

loans.name: Njira

texts.en:
Njira is a single mother of two school aged children. They live in a house that they own, which does not have electricity nor piped water. Her greatest monthly expenses are food and school fees.

She has operated a food business cooking beans, flat bread and rice and selling to her neighbors and passersby.  Njira faces a major challenge of seasonality in her business. During the rainy season she experiences low customer turn-out. Njira dreams of expanding her business in the future. 

With the KES 20,000, she wants to purchase one bundle of wheat flour, maize flour and sugar for her food business. She decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost her business.

loans.use: to purchase one bundle of wheat flour, maize flour and sugar for her food business.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy baking flour, maize flour, sugar and rice.

loans.name: Koumba

texts.fr:
Madame Koumba C. est âgée de 47 ans, mariée et mère de 3 enfants, elle vit avec ses enfants au quartier Pelengana sud avec plusieurs locataires, de la ville de Ségou (quatrième région administrative de la république du Mali).
Aide soignante de formation, en plus de ce métier, elle excelle dans les activités commerciales. Des articles électro-ménagers avec les téléviseurs, radios, magnétoscopes etc, elle opta pour l’achat vente des produits alimentaires tels le riz, le lait en poudre etc. Elle mène cette activité depuis 16 ans et bénéfice d’une clientèle fidèle qui est généralement le personnel  socio sanitaire et autres fonctionnaires.
 Dans le dessein d’augmenter son fonds de commerce pour faire face à la demande clientèle, elle a  fait recours à Soro Yiriwaso, elle est en relation avec cette dernière depuis 66 mois, après avoir fait 3 prêts solidaires et 4 prêts  individuels tous  bien remboursés, elle est à son 5ème prêt individuel qu’elle compte utiliser pour acheter 8 sacs de lait en poudre, elle s’approvisionne à Tombouctou.  
Madame Koumba C. vend au comptant et à crédit à une clientèle composée d’hommes et de femmes. Elle envisage réaliser un bénéfice mensuel 90 000 FCFA,qui permettra de prendre en charge les dépenses familiales et de terminer sa maison en construction
texts.en:
Mrs Koumba C., age 47, is married and the mother of three children. She lives with her children and several renters in Pelengana Sud, a neighborhood in the city of Ségou (fourth administrative region of the Republic of Mali).

A trained auxiliary nurse, she also excels in business. Instead of appliances such as televisions, radios, video recorders, she chose to sell food products such as rice, powdered milk, etc. She's been running this business for 16 years, and has faithful customers, mainly among socio-sanitary workers and other public servants.

Aiming to bolster her working capital to meet customer demand, she turned to Kiva's partner, Soro Yiriwaso, which she's been in contact with for 66 months. After three group and 4 personal loans, all repaid without problems, she's seeking her fifth loan. She intends to use it to buy 8 sacks of powdered milk. She gets her supplies in Tombouctou.

Mrs. Koumba C. selles for cash and on credit, to a clientele comprising both men and women. She intends to turn an average monthly profit of XOF 90'000 (ca US$ 200), which will enable her to take care of the family expenses and finish building her home.

loans.use: to buy 8 sacks of powdered milk

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to purchase and insure a dairy cow

loans.name: Anvarshoh

texts.en:
Anvarshoh A. is a focused and active single man. He is from Dushanbe, Tajikistan.  From childhood he has been interested in agriculture, and today he is engaged in animal husbandry. He sells cattle in the market located in Vahdat city.  Every week he purchases cattle for 1500 to 1700 Somoni and sells them for 1800 to 2000 Somoni. He has been in this business for 3 years. Besides that, he also sells vegetables and milk.  Anvarshoh would like to get a loan of 7000 Somoni to expand his business.  


More about Tajikistan and IMON International

Tajikistan is known for its rich history, which includes a key post along the Silk Road and the end of Alexander the Great's rule. It has also produced great thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets, including Rudaki, Avicenna, Ferdowsi, Omar Khayyam, Jomi, and Rumi. The country is home to communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language, epic mountain passes, and a civilization that dates back to the 4th millennium BC. And, even today, it is a complex mixture of the Islamic faith, Soviet culture, New West culture and Central Asian traditions.

But Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics. The civil war, which ignited soon after its independence from the U.S.S.R., further damaged the already weak economy. In addition, 93% of the country is mountainous and only 7% of the land is arable. These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia. While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural production and manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population still live in abject poverty.

IMON's History

Since December 2007, IMON International has worked closely with Kiva and Kiva lenders to ensure that poor and low income clients represent a viable business proposition. Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj

loans.use: to buy cattle

loans.name: Benk Group

texts.fr: Les femmes du groupe BENK sont toutes mariées et ont une moyenne d’âge de 30 ans et de 3 enfants. Elles vivent dans les familles conjugales élargies traditionnelles avec leurs frères, sœurs, co-épouses, enfants et époux. Elles résident dans le village de DIOUTIEBOUGOU de la préfecture de BOUGOUNI, troisième région administrative de la république du Mali. Ces femmes se sont connues par des relations de parenté. Après avoir rencontré beaucoup de difficultés à acheter des condiments au comptant avec leurs fournisseurs, elles ont décidé d’adhérer à  l’institution de micro finance Soro Yiriwaso afin de développer leur pouvoir d’achat et cela pour faire la restauration et le commerce de charbons de bois. Elles sont à leur neuvième prêt de groupe et tous les prêts précédents ont été correctement remboursés. Avec ce prêt ces Mariam D. compte acheter, 25 sacs de charbons de bois et 10 chargements de charrette en bois de chauffe avec les producteurs de charbon de DIOUTIEBOUGOU. Elle revend en détail ou en gros, au comptant et à crédit à une clientèle composée essentiellement de femmes. Avec ce prêt les femmes désirent obtenir un bénéfice mensuel de 25 000 FCFA qui sera utilisé pour soutenir les frais de santé et d’éducation des enfants.
texts.en:
The members of the BENK group are all married women who average 30 years of age and three children each. They live in extended traditional conjugal families with their brothers, sisters, co-wives, children, and husbands. They reside in the village of DIOUTIEBOUGOU, in the prefecture of BOUGOUNI, third administrative region of the Republic of Mali. They know one another through family ties. 

Having encountered many difficulties in buying condiments for cash from their suppliers, they decided to join the microfinance institution Soro Yiriwaso to bolster their purchasing power in order to pursue their food services and charcoal sales activities. This is their ninth group loan, and all previous loans were correctly repaid. 

Mrs. Mariam D. will use her loan to buy 25 bags of charcoal and 10 cartloads of firewood from the coal producers of DIOUTIEBOUGOU. She sells at retail and wholesale, for cash and credit, to a mostly female clientele. 

With this loan, the members expect to earn a monthly profit of 25,000 FCFA, which will be used to cover the children’s health care expenses and school fees.

loans.use: to purchase charcoal and firewood

loans.name: Giyosiddin

texts.en:
M. Giyosiddin is married and has three children. He is from Dushanbe, Tajikistan. He is engaged in animal husbandry. He sells cattle in the market located in Vahdat city.  Every week he purchases cattle for 1600 to 1800 Somoni and sells them for 2000 to 2300 Somoni. He has been in this business for 3 years. Besides that he also sells vegetables in the market. He plans to purchase cattle and is asking for a loan of 7000 Somoni.   


More about Tajikistan and IMON International

Tajikistan is known for its rich history, which includes a key post along the Silk Road and the end of Alexander the Great's rule. It has also produced great thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets, including Rudaki, Avicenna, Ferdowsi, Omar Khayyam, Jomi, and Rumi. The country is home to communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language, epic mountain passes, and a civilization that dates back to the 4th millennium BC. And, even today, it is a complex mixture of the Islamic faith, Soviet culture, New West culture and Central Asian traditions.

But Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics. The civil war, which ignited soon after its independence from the U.S.S.R., further damaged the already weak economy. In addition, 93% of the country is mountainous and only 7% of the land is arable. These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia. While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural production and manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population still live in abject poverty.

IMON's History

Since December 2007, IMON International has worked closely with Kiva and Kiva lenders to ensure that poor and low income clients represent a viable business proposition. Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj

loans.use: to buy cattle

loans.name: Benard

texts.en: Benard is a 41-year-old business man.  He sells sugarcane for a living.  To supplement his family’s income, he does farming.  He is able to educate his two children with the income from his business.  Since he joined Faulu Kenya, he has improved his business hence his living standards.  He hopes to become a major supplier of sugarcane in his area in the future.   He has requested  50,000 Kenyan shillings (KES) to rent a room for storing sugarcane, pay for labor, and add to his stock of sugarcane.

loans.use: to rent a room for storing sugarcane, pay for labor, and buy sugarcane

loans.name: Djamadjigui Group

texts.fr:
Le groupe DJAMADJIGUI est composé de femmes mariées qui ont une moyenne d’âge de 32 ans et de 4 enfants. Elles vivent dans des familles conjugales nucléaires avec leurs enfants et époux. Ces femmes résident dans le village de DIOUTIEBOUGOU, préfecture de BOUGOUNI, troisième région administrative de la république du Mali. Ces femmes se sont connues par des relations de commerce. Avec l’idée d’améliorer leur pouvoir d’achat, elles ont décidé d’adhérer à  l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso et cela pour faire le commerce d’articles divers, des céréales et du miel. Elles sont à leur sixième prêt de groupe et les prêts précédents ont été bien remboursés. Avec ce prêt Fanta D.  compte acheter 100 litres miel avec les paysans de DIOUTIEBOUGOU et environnants pour les revendre ensuite en gros et en détail, au comptant et à crédit sur le marché BOUGOUNI. Leur clientèle est composée d’hommes et de femmes. 
Avec ce prêt les femmes espèrent obtenir un bénéfice mensuel de  25 000 FCFA qui sera utilisé dans l’entretien de leurs enfants.
texts.en:
The group DJAMADJIGUI is composed of married women who average 32 years of age and four children each. The women live in conjugal nuclear families with their children and husband, and they reside in the village of DIOUTIEBOUGOU, in the prefecture of BOUGOUNI (3rd administrative region of the Republic of Mali). They know one another through business ties. With the idea of improving their buying power, they decided to join the micro-finance institution Soro Yiriwaso for doing commerce in a variety of goods, grains, and honey. The group members are on their sixth group loan. The previous ones have been fully repaid.

With her loan, Fanta D. intends to buy 100 liters of honey from peasant farmers in and around DIOUTIEBOUGOU to be sold wholesale and retail, cash or credit accepted, at the BOUGOUNI market. The customer base comprises women and men.

Using this loan, the women hope to obtain a monthly profit of 25,000 francs CFA that will be used to care for their children.

loans.use: to buy honey

loans.name: Mwanajuma

texts.en:
Mwanajuma is a single woman with one child who attends school. She owns a house that has piped water but not electricity. Her greatest monthly expense is school fees.

For the past 10 years, she has operated a retail shop, selling to her neighbours and passersby. Her greatest monthly expenses are food and school fees. Mwanajuma dreams of expanding her business in the future.

With the 20,000 Kenyan shilling (KES) loan she wants to purchase bundles of wheat flour, maize flour, rice and sugar. She decided to work with Yehu to access funds to boost her business.

loans.use: to purchase bundles of wheat flour, maize flour, rice and sugar

loans.name: Djiguisseme Group

texts.fr:
Les membres du groupe DJIGUISSEME sont toutes mariées et ont une moyenne d’âge de 34 ans et 3 enfants. Elles vivent dans des familles conjugales traditionnelles élargies avec leurs frères, sœurs, co-épouses, enfants et époux. Ces femmes résident dans à DIOUTIEBOUGOU  préfecture de BOUGOUNI, (troisième région administrative de la république du Mali). Ces  femmes se sont connues par des relations de commerce, de parenté et de voisinage. 
Pour satisfaire leurs clientèles qui ne cessent de croître, elles ont décidé d’adhérer à l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso. Elles sont à leur premier prêt de groupe. 
Avec ce  prêt Mama D., compte acheter, 500Kg de graine d’arachide et 300kg de beurre de karité auprès des fournisseurs des villages environnants. Elle effectue sa vente en détail et en gros, au comptant et à crédit, à domicile et au marché de Bougouni, aux consommateurs et revendeurs. 
Avec ce prêt Mama D. espère réaliser un bénéfice mensuel de 30.000 FCFA qui sera utilisé pour les dépenses de la famille.
texts.en:
The members of the DJIGUISSEME group are all married; they are on average 34 years old and have three children. They live in extended traditional families with their brothers, sisters, co-wives, children, and husbands. These women reside in DIOUTIEBOUGOU, in BOUGOUNI prefecture (third administrative region of the Republic of Mali). These women got to know each other through trade, family and neighborly relations.
To meet the demand of their ever-growing client base, they decided to join the Soro Yiriwaso microfinance institution. This is their first loan as a group.
With this loan, Mama D. plans on purchasing 500 kilos of peanuts and 300 kilos of peanut butter from suppliers based in neighboring villages. She resells both retail and wholesale, takes cash and credit, door-to-door and on the Bougouni market, to both consumers and retailers.
With this loan, Mama D. hopes to make a monthly benefit of FCFA 30,000, which will be used for her family's expenses.

loans.use: to purchase food products

loans.name: Umarali

texts.en:
Umarali is a hard-working man who has two children. His wife is a housewife. He lives in Dushanbe, Tajikistan. He works in the market in Vahdat city. Umarali sells household goods such as perfume, sweets, drinks and etc. Umarali requested a loan of 4500 Somoni for the purchase of additional goods and to increase his working capital, which will allow him to expand his business. 
 
More about Tajikistan and IMON International

Tajikistan is known for its rich history, which includes a key post along the Silk Road and the end of Alexander the Great's rule. It has also produced great thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets, including Rudaki, Avicenna, Ferdowsi, Omar Khayyam, Jomi, and Rumi. The country is home to communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language, epic mountain passes, and a civilization that dates back to the 4th millennium BC. And, even today, it is a complex mixture of the Islamic faith, Soviet culture, New West culture and Central Asian traditions.

But Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics. The civil war, which ignited soon after its independence from the U.S.S.R., further damaged the already weak economy. In addition, 93% of the country is mountainous and only 7% of the land is arable. These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia. While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural production and manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population still live in abject poverty.

IMON's History

Since December 2007, IMON International has worked closely with Kiva and Kiva lenders to ensure that poor and low income clients represent a viable business proposition. Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj

loans.use: to buy additional goods

loans.name: Naomi

texts.en: Naomi was born in 1958, she lives with her two children.  She sells clothes to earn a living.  Being a single-mother of two, she works hard in her business so as to get enough income to educate her children.  She has been running her business for thirteen years. She has sustained her business because of the support from Faulu Kenya.  With a loan of 50,000 Kenyan shillings,she will buy blouses.

loans.use: to buy blouses

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to purchase poultry

loans.name: Faïda Group

texts.fr:
Le groupe FAÏDA est composé des six femmes mariées qui ont une moyenne d’âge de 32 ans, 3 enfants et qui vivent dans des familles conjugales traditionnelles avec leurs frères, sœurs, co-épouses, enfants et époux. Ces femmes résident dans le village de DIOUTIEBOUGOU préfecture de BOUGOUNI,  troisième région administrative de la république du Mali. Ces femmes se sont connues par des relations de voisinage et de parenté. 
Pour mener à bien leurs activités commerciales, elles ont décidé d’adhérer à  l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso et cela pour faire le commerce de céréales. Elles sont à leur sixième prêt de groupe et tous les cinq précédents ont été correctement remboursés. Avec ce prêt Chata C. compte acheter auprès des fournisseurs de DIOUTIEBOUGOU et environs, 1 tonne de petit mil, 400kg de fonio et 600kg maïs, qui seront revendus aux grossistes en détail et au comptant dans le marché de BOUGOUNI à une clientèle est composée d’hommes et de femmes. Avec ce prêt elles comptent avoir  un bénéfice mensuel de 17.500 FCFA qui sera utilisé dans leurs activités.
texts.en:
The FAÏDA group is made up of six married women who are an average of 32 years old, have three children, and live in large extended families with their brothers, sisters, co-wives, children and husbands.  These women live in the Village of Dioutiebougou, a prefecture of Bougouni, the third administrative region of the Rupublic of Mali.  The women know each other as neighbors and through kinship ties.

To better manage their businesses, they decided to join the microfinance institution of Soro Yiriwaso in order to purchase and sell grains.  They are on their sixth group loan, and all five of their previous loans were fully reimbursed.  With this loan, Chata C. intends to purchase one ton of millet, 400kg of fonio, and 600kg of maize from the suppliers in Dioutiebougou and its surroundings.  These goods will be resold to wholesalers in the market of Bougouni in smaller quantities for cash to a clientele made up of men and women.
