loans.name: Osman

texts.en:
This is 30-year-old Osman K..  He is married, and has 4 children aged 4, 10 12 and 12 years. In 2006, Osman established his electronics business. He began his business to enable him to generate enough income to support his family.  Working 6 days a week and 10 hours a day, he earns about Le 400,000 every month from this business. 

Osman would like a loan in the amount of Le 4,000,000. He requires a loan in order to buy different type of radios and electric lamps for his business. He hopes this loan will enable him to increase his monthly profits by approximately Le 300,000. In the future, Osman plans to open a bigger shop, educate children and buy a piece of land. He thanks you for your support.

loans.use: to buy different type of radios and electric lamps

loans.name: Mustapha

texts.en: This is 31 year-old Mustapha K..  He is married, and has 4 children ages 3, 6, 10 and 12 years. In 2006, Mustapha established his essential drugs business. He began his business because he believes this business will help him provide livelihood for his family. Working 6 days a week and 10 hours a day, he earns about Le 350,000 every month from this business. He would like a loan in the amount of Le 4,500,000. Mustapha requires a loan in order to add more stock to business for more profit. He hopes that this loan will enable him to increase his monthly profits by approximately Le 250,000. In the future, Mustapha plans to open a bigger shop, educate his children to university level and build a house for his family. He thanks you for your support.

loans.use: To buy more essential drugs for his business

loans.name: Hasanatu

texts.en: This is 32 year-old Hassanatu B..  She is married, and has 1 child who is 12 years old. In 2006, Hassanatu established her assorted food stuff business. She began her business because she wants to generate income and support her child.  Working 6 days a week and 10 hours a day, she earns about Le 300,000 every month from this business. She would like a loan in the amount of Le 3,000,000. Hassanatu requires a loan in order to buy more food items for her business. She hopes that this loan will enable her to increase her monthly profits by approximately Le 250,000. In the future, Hassanatu plans to educate her children and establish a savings account. She thanks you for your support.

loans.use: To buy imported food items for her business

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To buy more essential drugs for his pharmacy

loans.name: Isatu B

texts.en: This is 37 year-old Isatu B. S..  She is married, and has 3 children ages 2, 7, and 9, years. In 2009, Isatu established her baby items business. She began her business because she wanted to generate income and help her husband to provide livelihood for their family.  Working 6 days a week and 10 hours a day, she earns about Le 300,000 every month from this business. She would like a loan in the amount of Le 4,000,000. Isatu requires a loan in order to buy the following goods for her business - Baby shirts, pants, powder, Vaseline etc. She hopes that this loan will enable her to increase her monthly profits by approximately Le 250,000. In the future, Isatu plans to buy larger quantities to supply to other traders and open another stall. She thanks you for your support.

loans.use: To buy boxes of baby shirts, pants, baby powder and Vaseline

loans.name: Saidu

texts.en: This is 45 year-old Saidu K..  He is married, and has 4 children ages 2, 7, 9, and 12 years. In 1996, Saidu established his used clothing business. He began his business because he wants to be self employed so that he can have a sustainable means of providing livelihood for his family. Working 6 days a week and 10 hours a day, he earns about Le 250,000 every month from this business. He would like a loan in the amount of Le 3,000,000. Saidu requires a loan in order to buy bales of used clothing for his business. He hopes that this loan will enable him to increase his monthly profits by approximately Le 300,000. In the future, Saidu plans to buy larger quantity of used clothing and supply other traders in used clothing. He thanks you for your support.

loans.use: To buy ready-made clothing for his business

loans.name: Inshirah

texts.en:
Inshirah H. is a 46-year-old married woman who has three children.

Inshirah decided to do something in her life so she can feel productive and to help in supporting her family. That’s when, one year ago,  she started a small home business selling few types of cosmetics. 

Through this one year she widened her product base to include more types of cosmetics, accessories and clothes, and gained a good reputation among her neighbors. In the meantime she is depending on word of mouth as a way to attract more customers.

Now Inshirah is applying for a loan to buy more products in order to cover as much  of the customers’ needs in her area as she can.

loans.use: To buy more cosmetics and accessories for resale.

loans.name: Hanan

texts.en:
Hanan Q., a 60-year-old proactive woman, has been helping her family by selling all types of blankets and bedroom covers for 11 years now. 

Hanan applied for this loan in order to add more variety to her products by including clothes, and she want to have her own retail store in the future so she can be able to display her products more easily.

loans.use: To add more variety to her product line by including clothes.

loans.name: Anibal

texts.es:
El Sr. Anibal de 59 años de edad, un ejemplar padre soltero con cuatros hijos, reside en el barrio Santa Lucia de la ciudad de Ita, se dedica a la venta de menudencias por las noches como ser: asaditos, chorizo casero y empanadas, como también por las mañanas sale a vender ropas interiores acompañado de su hijo quien le ayuda en las ventas.
Él cuenta que anteriormente se dedicaba a la venta de pan de miel y luego de eso trabajó en montajes de antenas por el chaco, pero hoy en día solo realiza su trabajo por la ciudad para estar más cerca de sus hijos.
El crédito que esta solicitando es para la compra de carne para la producción de chorizo casero ya que se demanda mucho dicho producto.
Su objetivo principal es la de ver recibido como profesionales a sus hijos y crecer en el negocio.
texts.en:
Anibal is 59 years old.  He is an exemplary single father who has four children.  He lives in Santa Lucia neighborhood, in the city of Ita.

In the evenings, Anibal sells food such as roast meat, home-made chorizo and empanadas.  In the mornings, he goes out to sell underwear accompanied by his son who helps him make his sales.

Anibal tells us that he used to sell 'pan de miel' (honey bread), then he worked installing aerials in rural areas but now he only carries out his work in the city so that he can be closer to his children.

Anibel will use the loan that he is requesting to buy meat for making his home-made chorizo since he has a lot of demand for it.  His main goal is to see his children become professionals and to grow his business.

loans.use: to buy meat

loans.name: Delia Caritina

texts.es:
La Sra Delia. tiene 48 años D. edad, está casada con el señor  Estanislao S. quien es carpintero y le ayuda con  los gastos del hogar, son Curuguateños antiguos. Tienen cinco hijos mayores todos independientes, a quienes han criado con mucho esfuerzo y sacrificio.
Delia tiene un copetin, desD. hace mas D. 5 años.  Su esposo era el único que generaba ingresos en la casa,  y con un pequeño capital que había juntado pudieron montar dicha actividad. Hoy día ambos generan ingresos y aportan a la canasta familiar.
Actualmente posee clientela formada, pues su negocio está ubicado frente a Identificaciones donD. concurre mucha gente cada dia.
Necesita el crédito para la compra D. mercaderias como carne, huevos, bebidas y otros.
texts.en:
Delia is 48 years old and married to Estanislao S., a carpenter, and she helps him to pay their living expenses: they are old Curuguateños. They have 5 grown children who all live independently, who were raised with great effort and sacrifice by their parents.

Delia has been running a snack bar for 5 years. Her husband was the only one bringing money into their home, and with the small amount of capital that they had saved, they were able to establish this business. Today they both earn money and contribute to the family bills.

Currently she has a regular client base as her business is located facing the Identificaciones building, where there is a lot of passing traD. each day. She needs the loan to purchase goods such as meat, eggs, drinks and more.

loans.use: For the purchase of goods such as meat, eggs, drinks and more.

loans.name: Diosnel

texts.es:
El Sr. Diosnel está casado con la sra. Tomasa, tienen 10 hijos todos ya mayores, desde muy joven empezó a trabajar con su tío en la plantación de frutas y verduras.
El se dedica a la plantacion de espinaca, perejil , acelga y otros verdeos, tambien se dedica a la venta de verduras en forma ambulante por los barrios de su ciudad, gracias a la calidad de productos que ofrece ya  tiene una buena cantidad de clientela formada. 
El necesita de este crédito para la comprar de tomate, cebolla y locote, ya que tiene cantidad de pedidos y de esta manera podrá obtener mejores ganancias.
Diosnel  anhela en el futuro comprar más terreno y poder ampliar su rubro.
texts.en:
Diosnel is married to Tomasa, they have 10 grown children. From an early age he has worked with his uncle on a fruit and vegetable plantation.

He works hard planting spinach, parsley, chard and other greens, he also walks through the city's neighborhoods selling his vegetables. He has developed a good-sized client base thanks to the quality produce that he has to offer.

He needs this loan to purchase tomatoes, onions, and chilies to fulfill his orders and so be able to increase his earnings.

Diosnel hopes to buy more land in the future and to be able to increase his lot.

loans.use: For the purchase of tomato, onion and chili.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to purchase flour, sugar, dairy products, baked goods and meat as well as corn in bulk to feed her pigs.

loans.name: Pedro

texts.es:
El Sr. Pedro D. F. es cliente recurrente de Kiva, el mismo es casado y vive en casa propia en la ciudad de Luque con su cónyuge y su hijo.
El titular y su pareja se dedican a la venta de ropas en forma independiente por el Chaco paraguayo, además en el transcurso de la tarde realiza trabajos de compostura de calzados. A la fecha este es el sexto préstamo que el titular solicita para invertir en su negocio de venta de ropas.
Dicho préstamo el titular considera que le dará un mejor ingreso para mejorar su nivel de vida, de él mismo y la de su familia.
Se ha esmerado en cumplir al día con sus cuotas en créditos anteriores, por ello se le concede este espacio nuevamente para su nueva solicitud de apoyo económico.
texts.en: Señor Pedro D. F. is a returning Kiva client.  He is married and lives in his own home in the city of Luque with his wife and son.  The proprietor and his wife sell clothing independently around the Paraguayan Chaco and during the afternoon he repairs footwear.  He is requesting his sixth loan and will use it to invest in his clothing sales business.  With the loan he will be able to earn a better income to improve his quality of life and that of his family. He has taken great pains to make the payments on his previous loans and because of this he has been granted the opportunity to request another loan.

loans.use: to purchase clothing.

loans.name: Librada

texts.es:
La Sra. Librada es comerciante hace mas de 6 años, tiene una librería y fotocopiadora a una cuadra de la Facultad UPAP de la ciudad de Coronel Oviedo.
Ella es divorciada con dos hijos, que ya son mayores de edad, uno se llama Marcos y trabaja con ella en la librería realizando trabajos a computadora, comenta que tiene muy buena clientela, ya que tiene muy buena ubicación y cuenta con local propio.
La sra. Librada agradece a la Fundacion Paraguaya por la confianza puesta en su persona y la oportunidad de solicitar un crédito en Kiva y asegura que invertirá bien su préstamo, para poder devolverlo en tiempo y forma, para poder seguir trabajando con la institución.
Ella solicita este crédito para poder comprar otra computadora con la cual trabajar.
texts.en:
Librada has been a saleswoman for more than six years.  She has a bookstore and photocopying business which is located one block from UPAP (Universidad Politécnica y Artística de Paraguay), in the city of Coronel Oviedo. 

Librada is divorced and has two children who are already grown up.  One is called Marcos and works with her in the bookstore, doing work for people on a computer.  Librada tells us that she has a very good customer base because her store is well located and she owns her own premises.

Librada is grateful to Fundación Paraguaya for the trust that they have placed in her and the opportunity that they have given her to request a loan through Kiva.  She assures us that she will invest her loan well so that she can pay it back on time and in full, as she would like to be able to continue working with the institution.

Librada is requesting this loan so that she can buy another computer with which to work.

loans.use: to buy another computer

loans.name: Raquel Castro Group

texts.en:
Raquel C. is 37 years old and is from the village of Esperanza West. She is the group leader of the Raquel C. Group, an eight-member group loan with ASKI. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are all collectively responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults.

Raquel is married and has two school-aged children. To make a living, she owns and operates a specialized retail store. Raquel's main source of income comes from selling daily use products such as shampoo, soap, and toothpaste in the local community. She has been engaged in her business for over six years and earns approximately 4,000 PHP a month.

Raquel joined ASKI in 2011 to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. She is requesting a loan of 7,000 PHP to purchase items to expand her store inventory. This is the first loan taken out by Raquel from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from her loan to improve and expand her business.


About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 38 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase items to expand store inventory

loans.name: Myrian

texts.es:
Myrian tiene 48 años de edad, está casada con el señor Héctor Vargas quien es mecánico-tornero y le ayuda con  los gastos del hogar, vino a Carapeguá  hace más de 20 años. Tienen cinco hijos, a quienes han criado con mucho esfuerzo y sacrificio.
Myrian se dedica al ramo de la despensa desde hace más de 20 años. Cuando su marido y ella se mudaron a la ciudad, su esposo era el único que generaba ingresos por que se dedica a la mecánica de automóvil y con un pequeño capital que había juntado pudieron montar dicha actividad. Hoy día ambos generan ingresos y aportan a la canasta familiar.
Actualmente posee clientela formada, pues su negocio está ubicado cerca de una fábrica de cueros en donde hay varios empleados, la mayoría clientes que compran en su negocio.
Necesita el crédito para la compra de mercaderias como fideos, galletas, gaseosas, arroz y otros.
texts.en:
Myrian is a 48-year-old woman who is married to Mr. Hector Vargas, a lathe operator who helps with the household expenses. She came to Carapeguá over 20 years ago. They have 5 children whom they have raised with much work and sacrifice.

Myrian has been running a general store for over 20 years. When she and her husband moved to the city, her husband was the only one who earned a living; he is an auto mechanic. With a bit of capital that they had saved, they were able to set up this business. Today, they both earn an income and contribute to the family expenses.

She currently has a solid client-base since her business is located near a leather factory with many workers, the majority of whom shop at her store.

She needs this loan in order to purchase goods such as noodles, cookies, soft drinks, rice, and other products.

loans.use: to purchase goods such as noodles, cookies, soft drinks, rice, and other products.

loans.name: Renacer Group

texts.es:
El comité se inició gracias a la señora Gladys F., domiciliada en el Barrio Niño Jesús distante a 22km de la oficina de Carapeguá.
“Renacer” fue denominado el comité y actualmente se encuentra en el ciclo Nro. 14 con 15 integrantes, es un grupo de señoras muy responsables y trabajadoras, ellas se dedican a diversas actividades tales como: venta de lencerías, venta de comidas, despensa, venta de ropas, etc.
Algunas de las integrantes ya contaban con trabajo antes de formar parte del comité de Mujeres Emprendedoras y se integraron para lograr mejorar su emprendimiento, otras sin embargo comienzan con su primera actividad independiente a los que se refiere al cuidado de su familia.
Las mujeres agradecen a la Fundacion Paraguaya por la iniciativa ya que mediante ella lograron desarrollar bastante  su capacidad de trabajo en equipo.
La Sra. Crescencia se dedica hace varios años a la venta de ropas, ella se levanta muy temprano a preparar su bolsa para salir a vender. La venta lo realiza de forma ambulante y ahora mediante créditos anteriores lo realiza en una motocicleta.
La Sra. Crescencia agradece de manera especial a la Fundacion por que mediante el apoyo brindado por la misma pudo adquirir más capital y aumentar su negocio, pero ahora solicita el crédito nuevamente para adquirir más ropas que vender y crear su propio salón de venta de ropas.
texts.en:
This group was started thanks to Ms. Gladys F., who lives in the Niño Jesús neighborhood, some 22 km away from the Carapeguá office.

The group was named Renacer, and it is currently in its 14th loan cycle. This group is comprised of 15 very hardworking and responsible women who sell things like lingerie, food, groceries, and apparel, among other goods.

Some of the women already had a job before joining the group, nevertheless, they joined because they wanted to improve their businesses. Other members, however, are working for the first time, not counting looking after their families.

These women thank Fundacion Paraguaya for the help because with it, they have been able to develop their work skills as a team.

Ms. Crescencia has been selling apparel for several years. She gets up very early in the morning to go out and sell her merchandise. She is a street vendor, and now, because of her previous loans, she uses a motorcycle for work.

Ms. Crescencia would like to give special thanks to Fundacion Paraguaya because with their help, she has been able to increase her capital and expand her business, but she is once again requesting a loan so that she can obtain more apparel and set up her own clothing store.

loans.use: to purchase winter apparel and obtain a business space.

loans.name: Renee

texts.en:
Renee is a 24-year-old woman from Daliyat HaCarmel. In 2005 she opened her hair salon on a central and busy location in the village of Reineh. Last year Renee completed studies in bridal hair styles and designs. She has now expanded her salon to include bridal party clients and wedding styles. Renee invested in redesigning her salon and purchasing needed equipment for the additional styles. Renee is taking advantage of special Business Development Courses offered by the Israeli SBA. She has taken these lessons and put them into practice with the expansion and development of her salon.

She needs this loan for additional supplies, hairdressing stations and furniture for her salon.

Over the next two months Renee already has 15 wedding clients reserved on top of her regular salon clientele. Renee dreams in the future of opening a full Bridal Salon with makeup artists, dress designers, apparel rental and hair stylists. She is on the path to reach this dream.

loans.use: Additional supplies, hairdressing stations and furniture for her salon.

loans.name: Kazita

texts.en:
Kazita, a 39-year-old mother of three, is from the northern village of Reineh.  She began working in insurance sales while she was still studying for her degree. In March she opened her insurance office and serves clients from her village and the surrounding area. There are no other insurance offices in her village so her client base is growing steadily.

Kazita needed this loan to purchase office equipment, a computer, a printer-fax-scanner & furniture.

In the future Kazita wants to continue to expand and bring on additional sales staff and create a thriving, profitable insurance company.

loans.use: Purchase office equipment, a computer, a printer-fax-scanner & furniture.

loans.name: Anna

texts.en:
Anna is a 42-year-old divorced mother of two. Originally from Russia, Anna moved to Israel in the mid 90s. She opened her manicure-pedicure business in 2008 and has succeeded in earning a decent income for her family. She works out of a hair salon in Tel Aviv. 

Anna decided to expand her business into cosmetics, providing make-up artistry and cosmetic sales. After completing studies in cosmetics, Anna began her expansion with success.

Anna needs this loan to purchase modern cosmetic equipment and professional make-up supplies.

Anna wants to continue providing quality services and expanding her client base. Her dream is to ensure a strong a bright future for her children.

loans.use: to purchase modern cosmetic equipment and professional make-up supplies.

loans.name: Zenaida

texts.en:
Zenaida P. is 31 years old and married with two school-aged children. She is from the village of Nuesa. To make a living, Zenaida owns and operates a business raising crops. Her main source of income comes from planting and harvesting a variety of vegetables to sell. Zenaida has been engaged in her business for over seven years and earns approximately 4,000 PHP a month.

Zenaida joined ASKI in 2011 to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. She is requesting a loan of 10,000 PHP to purchase fertilizer such as manure. This will be Zenaida’s first loan from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from her loan to pay tuition fees for her children.

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 38 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase fertilizer such as manure

loans.name: Carol

texts.en:
Carol J. is 44 years old and married with five school-aged children. She is from the village of Centro 2. To make a living, Carol owns and operates a butcher shop. Her main source of income comes from butchering and selling poultry in the market. Carol has been engaged in her business for over 20 years and earns approximately 10,000 PHP a month. 

Carol joined ASKI in 2011 to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. She is requesting a loan of 15,000 PHP to purchase additional chicken meat to sell in the market. This will be the first loan taken out by Carol from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from her loan to pay tuition fees for her children. 


About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 38 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional chicken meat to sell in the market

loans.name: Sagrada Familia Group

texts.es:
El presente comité se inició por la señora Laura B., ex integrante del comité de Mujeres Virgen del Carmen. Ella contactó con sus vecinas y amigas para formar el comité "Sagrada Familia" en la zona.
El comité está en el  Tercer  ciclo con 23  integrantes, es un grupo que se destaca  en el barrio por ser muy unido, solidario y responsable, las mismas integrantes realizan labores para la recaudación de fondos para el grupo como: Rondas, Polladas y Sorteos.
La sra. Angelina se dedica a la venta de ropas desde hace muchos años, lo hace de manera ambulante, por las casas, los mercados y tiendas varias, es el medio por el cual ella sustenta a su familia y a ella misma, pues no quiere depender de otra persona para mantenerse económicamente, cree que todos somos capaces de generar nuestros propios ingresos con o sin sacrificio, pero reconoce que solicitar créditos es un medio que las ayuda mucho a sobresalir en sus labores, por eso necesita del préstamo económico de Kiva, para poder aumentar la cantidad de ropas que ofrece a sus diversos clientes, quiere invertirlo en la compra de pantalones, remeras, camperas, abrigos en general, etc.
texts.en:
This microfinance group was started by Ms. Laura B., an ex-member of the Mujeres Virgen del Carmen group. She got in touch with her friends and neighbors to form the Sagrada Familia group in the area.

This 23-member group is currently in its third loan cycle and is well-known in the neighborhood for being very united, supportive, and responsible. The same members have fundraisers like competitions, raffles, and social gatherings in which food is sold.

Ms. Angelina has been selling apparel on the streets, door-to-door, at open-air markets, and in various shops for many years. This is how she supports both her family and herself since she has no one else on whom to depend financially. She believes that we are all able to make our own living with or without sacrifice, but she recognizes that requesting loans is something that really helps people excel in their businesses, which is why she needs this loan from Kiva so that she can increase her merchandise. She would like to invest in purchasing pants, T-shirts, jackets, coats, etc.

loans.use: to purchase pants, jeans, jackets, caps, etc.

loans.name: Mujeres Activas De Candia Loma Group

texts.es:
Dicho comité es de la compañía Candia Loma de la ciudad de Caacupe, que dista a aproximadamente 10 km de la oficina. Está compuesto por 16 mujeres muy trabajadoras y unidas.
La presidenta, la Sra. Petrona G. vive con su marido e hijos, posee una pequeña despensa en su domicilio, también gracias a el programa de microfranquicias de la Fundacion Paraguaya pudo acceder al kit de anteojos sin receta para la reventa y así generar más ingresos para el sustento de su hogar.
Todas ellas están muy agradecidas con la Fundación Paraguaya porque gracias al crédito que percibieron en etapas anteriores y a las constantes capacitaciones pueden generar sus propios ingresos y así ayudar y dar mejor calidad de vida a sus familiares.
La sra. Petrona desea poder adquirir este crédito para poder comprar ropas de invierno y vender a sus exigentes clientes, generando mayores ingresos para su canasta familiar.
texts.en:
This microfinance group is from the Candia Loma rural area of the city of Caacupe, which is approximately 10 km from the regional office. This group is comprised of 16 very hardworking and united women.

The group president, Ms. Petrona G., lives with her husband and children. She owns a small in-home general store. Also, thanks to Fundación Paraguaya's microfinance program, she has been able to obtain non-prescription reading glasses so that she can resell them, thus generating more income for the household expenses.

These women are all very grateful to Fundación Paraguaya because thanks to their previous loans and to the constant training sessions, they are able to generate their own income and help provide a better quality of life for their families.

Ms. Petrona wishes to obtain this loan to purchase winter clothing to sell to her demanding customers, thus generating more money for the household.

loans.use: to purchase clothing for winter.

loans.name: Christina

texts.en:
Christina A. is from the village of San Rafael. She is 39 years old. Christina is married and has one school-aged child. To make a living, she owns and operates a general store, selling a variety of different products in the local community. She has been engaged in her business for over seven years and earns approximately $163 a month for these activities.

In 2007, Christina joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 15,000 PHP from ASKI. This previous loan was used to purchase new items to expand her product offering. 

Christina is requesting a new loan of 15,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This will be her 2nd loan from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to pay the tuition fees of her child. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful micro-finance institutions in the Philippines. It has 38 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Kuña Aty Porvenir Group

texts.es:
Las mujeres del presente comité son del barrio San José de la ciudad de Caacupe, que dista a 16 km de la oficina regional de dicha ciudad.
Las señoras  están en el ciclo Nº 2 con sus 13 integrantes.
La presidenta del comité es la señora Rudy Maricela C., vive con su marido, ella trabaja en venta de ropas, ella como también sus compañeras están muy satisfechas con el apoyo económico que les han brindado anteriormente la Fundación Paraguaya y Kiva, porque han aumentando sus pequeños negocios y así también sus ingresos para una mejor calidad de vida.
Sin embargo, desean seguir prosperando, por ello necesitan de otro préstamo con el que puedan adquirir lo que necesitan para alcanzar sus metas. La sra. Rudy por ejemplo, desea poder equipar su stock de productos con ropas para el frío, abrigos y pantalones principalmente.
Ellas están muy agradecidas y emocionadas por esta nueva solicitud, esperando contar con el respaldo que siempre han recibido.
texts.en:
The women of this microfinance group come from the San José neighborhood in the city of Caacupe, which is 16 km away from the city's regional office.

These 13 group members are currently in their 2nd loan cycle.

The group president is Ms. Rudy Maricela C., who lives with her husband. She sells apparel for a living. She and her fellow group members are very satisfied with the financial support that they have previously received from Fundación Paraguaya and Kiva because they have been able to expand their businesses and increase their profits for a better quality of life.

Nevertheless, they desire to keep prospering, which is why they need another loan with which they will be able to obtain what they need to reach their goals. Ms. Rudy, for example, hopes to be able to stock up on warm clothing, mainly coats and pants.

They are very grateful for and excited about this new loan, hoping to obtain the support that they have always received.

loans.use: to purchase coats and pants.

loans.name: Elizabeth

texts.en:
Elizabeth D. is from the village of Centro 2. She is 49 years old. Elizabeth is married and has six school-aged children. To make a living, she owns and operates a butcher shop, butchering and selling poultry meat in the market. She has been engaged in her business for over twenty-five years and earns approximately 5000 Php a month for these activities.

In 2011, Elizabeth joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. She is requesting a loan of 15,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional poultry meat in the market. This will be her 1st loan from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to pay the tuition fees of her children. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful micro-finance institutions in the Philippines. It has 38 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional poultry meat in the market

loans.name: Los Dos Olivos Group

texts.es:
La señora Edali  M. Vázquez, es integrante del grupo "Los dos olivos", que se ubica en la colonia "Juan Sabines", ella vive en unión libre con el señor Roberclein Hernández López y aun no tienen bebés.
     Ella solicito el préstamo para invertirlo en la compra de elotes para venderlos preparados en la misma localidad, se inspiro en esta actividad ya que también quiere apoyar a su esposo con los ingresos, y así juntos comenzar a horrar para progresar.
    Con las ganancias que obtenga invertirá nuevamente en el negocio, y además solventará algunos gastos de la casa.
   Lo que más desea es que con esta pequeña actividad y el crédito otorgado pueda seguir trabando, y así pueda comenzar a comprar algunas cosa para la construcción de su casa.
Los integrantes del grupo son:
María Elizabeth en la venta de antojitos.
Antonia Hernández López: compra y vende horchata de coco natural.
texts.en:
Ms. Edali M. Vázquez is a member of the Los Dos Olivos (The Two Olive Trees) microfinance group in the Juan Sabines housing development. She lives with her partner, Mr. Roberclein Hernández López, and they do not have any children yet.

She is requesting this loan in order to invest it in purchasing ears of corn to cook and sell in the same locality. She was inspired to start this business because she also wants to help her husband with an extra income, thus they can both start to save money and get ahead.

She will once again invest her profits into the business, plus she will pay for some household expenses.

What she desires most is that with this small business and with the loan she will receive, she will continue working so that she can start buying materials to build a house.

The other group members are: María Elizabeth, who sells street food. Antonia Hernández López, who buys and sells a sweet coconut beverage.

loans.use: to purchase ears of corn which will then be boiled and sold.

loans.name: Winky

texts.en:
Winky A. is from the village of Tipolohon, Claveria, Misamis Oriental. She is 34 years old. Winky is married and has three school-aged children. To make a living, Winky owns and operates a specialized retail store. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from buying and selling soft drinks in the local community. Winky has been engaged in her business for over five years and earns approximately 5,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2011, Winky joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Winky is requesting a new loan of 5,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional cases of several kinds of beverages. This loan will be the first loan taken out by Winky from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business.

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and reaches out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional cases of beverages.

loans.name: Tessie

texts.en:
Tessie works hard to support her family. Tessie is married. She has a business buying and selling peanuts in the Philippines.

Tessie requested a loan of PHP 20,000 through NWTF in order to buy additional stocks of peanuts to sell.

Tessie has been in this business for 4 years now.

In the future, Tessie would like to save money to expand her business.

loans.use: to buy additional stocks of peanuts to sell.

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Aurea

texts.en:
Aurea is 41 years old and married with six children. She works hard to provide for her family. She runs a sari-sari (variety) store in the Philippines and requested a PHP 15,000 loan through NWTF to buy additional items to sell like sardines, groceries, etc. in her sari-sari store.

Aurea has borrowed and repaid 13 loans from NWTF before this loan. She has been running the sari-sari store for two years and also earns an income from piggery and rice retailing.

Aurea aspires to build and expand her business and send her children to college.

loans.use: To buy additional items for her general store.

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Behilla

texts.en:
Behilla works hard to support her family. Behilla is separated and has a vegetable vending business in the Philippines. She requested a PHP 15,000 loan through NWTF to buy additional vegetables and herbs for her business.

Behilla has been in this business for 13 years now and also earns additional income from a "carinderia" (small cafe), buying and selling used clothing, buying and selling rice, and a BBQ stand.

In the future, Behilla would like to save money and expand her businesses.

loans.use: To buy additional vegetables and herbs for her business.

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Lucena

texts.en: Lucena is a hardworking entrepreneur who owns a multicab transport rental business in the Philippines. She is borrowing PHP 12,000 through NWTF to buy new equipment and tools for her business. Lucena has been three years in this business. She also earns additional income from dealing in RTW (Ready-To-Wear) clothing. Lucena has been sustaining her business activities through her own efforts with the help of the loans from NWTF. Her dream is to improve her business and to send her children to college in the future.

loans.use: to purchase new equipment and tools.

loans.name: Wilfreda

texts.en:
Wilfreda is a married woman with five children. She is a very hard-working entrepreneur. Wilfreda is 46 years old and has three children who are still in school.

Wilfreda has a jewelry business in the Philippines. She has requested a PHP 12,000 loan amount through NWTF to buy more jewelry to sell.

Wilfreda has been in this business for 20 years.  In the future, she would like to save enough money so she could afford to send her children to college.

loans.use: To purchase more jewelry to sell.

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Felly

texts.en:
Felly is 53 years old and married with one child. She is a very hard working entrepreneur.

Felly has a food production sales business in the Philippines. Felly requested a 10,000 Philippine peso loan amount through Kiva field partner NWTF to buy some ingredients for her food products to sell.

Felly has been in this business for 15 years. In the future, Felly would like to build and expand her business to secure the future of her family.

loans.use: To buy some ingredients for her food products business

loans.name: Mirasol

texts.en:
Mirasol is married with four children, and works hard to support her family.

She has a tricycle transport business in the Philippines, and also earns additional income from ready-to-wear clothing.  Mirasol is borrowing PHP 11,000 through NWTF to purchase new tools and equipment for her tricycle transport business.

Mirasol has been sustaining her business activities through her past 4 loans from NWTF. She hopes that her hard work will help her attain her dream to save enough to provide for the needs of her family.

loans.use: To purchase new tools and equipment

loans.name: Alma

texts.en:
Alma is a married woman with 4 children. She is a very hard-working entrepreneur. Alma is 41 years old and has one child who is in school.

Alma has a general store business in the Philippines. Alma requested a PHP 13,000 loan amount through NWTF to buy products and school supplies to sell in her general store.

Alma has been in this business for 2 years.  In the future, Alma would like to save enough money so she could afford to send her children to college.

loans.use: to purchase general store items and school supplies to sell

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Nera

texts.en: Nera, 36, is a married woman with 4 children — two of them in school. She is a very hard-working entrepreneur. Nera has a water-refilling business in the Philippines and requested a PHP 17,000 loan through NWTF to buy water containers. She has been in this business for six years. In the future, Nera would like to save enough money to send her children to college.

loans.use: To purchase container for her water refilling business

loans.name: Hanny Group

texts.es:
Este grupo solidario se llama Hanny está conformado por la señora Crispina va a comprar una licuadora y arpillas de naranja para sus jugos, la señora Dolores va a comprar papelería, la señora Silvestra va a comprar dulces por mayoreo, la señora Patricia va a comprar refrescos, verduras, carnes, gas, para surtir su negocio, la señora Erika va a comprar lencería para surtir su negocio.
Erika tiene 19 años de edad, ella estudio hasta el 3er año de secundaria, ella es soltera tiene 2 hijos Ángel Adair tiene seis meses y Kevin Jesús tiene 4 años,  ella tiene su negocio de venta de lencería  y bisutería, ella solicito su crédito para invertir en su negocio va a comprar sostenes, camisetas, pantaletas, ropa interior para niños y para niñas, bolitas diademas etc. Ella inicio su negocio hace 1 año con un dinero que tenia de unas tandas (forma popular de ahorro en mexico), ella empezó vendiendo gelatinas, después decidió poner su local bien establecido de lencería, su negocio es importante porque de ahí sostiene a su familia a sus hijos, ella se siente orgullosa de su trabajo y de atender bien a sus cliente, además con éste negocio ella puede cuidar a sus hijos; ella quiere ampliar su negocio quiere vender ropa de bebé y lo piensa lograr con las ganancias de la lencería. Sus sueños y esperanzas son que sus hijos crezcan sin carencias y que les pueda dejar un terreno o una propiedad y darles un buen estudio. Las integrantes del grupo les quieren decir a Kiva y a Fundación Realidad “les agradecemos por brindarnos la oportunidad de ayudarnos a emprender un negocio, para mí que soy madre soltera porque a veces es bueno que alguien nos ayude porque a veces no podemos solas, muchas gracias”
texts.en:
The Hanny microfinance group is comprised of Ms. Crispina, who will purchase a blender and sacks of oranges to make juice; Ms. Dolores, who will purchase stationery; Ms. Silvestra, who will purchase candy in bulk; Ms. Patricia, who will purchase soft drinks, vegetables, meats, and propane for her business; and Ms. Erika, who will purchase lingerie to restock her business.

Erika is a 19-year-old who studied up to the third year of middle school. She is single and has 2 children: Angel Adair, who is 6 months old, and Kevin Jesus, who is 4. She sells lingerie and fashion jewelry for a living. She has requested this loan in order to purchase bras, camisoles, panties, undergarments for boys and girls, twin bead ponytail holders, headbands, etc. She started this business a year ago with the money that she had from a tanda--a rotating savings and credit association, which is a popular form of saving money in Mexico. She started out selling gelatin, then decided to launch a lingerie business. This business is very important because she supports her family with it. She feels very proud of her work and of her good customer service. Furthermore, she is able to take care of her children with this business. She wants to expand her business by selling baby clothes, and she plans on doing so with the profits from the lingerie sales. She hopes that her children grow up without want, and dreams that she can give them either a plot of land or a property, as well as a good education. The members of this group would like to tell Kiva and Fundación Realidad that they are grateful for allowing them the opportunity to launch a business. Erika states, "For me, as a single mother, sometimes it is good receive help because at times, we cannot do it alone. Thank you."

loans.use: to purchase lingerie, bras, camisoles, and panties to restock her business.

loans.name: Rosita

texts.en:
Rosita B., 54, is a married woman with three children, one who is in school. She makes food which she sells.

Rosita requested a 15,000 PHP loan through NWTF to buy the ingredients she uses to make her food to sell. She is a very hardworking entrepreneur.

Rosita has been in this business for twelve years. Rosita would like to save enough money to renovate her home and send her children to college.

loans.use: To buy the ingredients she uses to make her food to sell

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Lucia

texts.en:
Lucia is 57 years old and married with six children. 

Lucia works hard to provide for her family. She runs a sari-sari store in the Philippines and requested a 12,000 Philippine peso (PHP) loan through NWTF to buy more items to sell in her sari-sari store. 

Lucia has borrowed and paid 10 loans from NWTF before this loan. She has been running the sari-sari store for five years and also earns an income from food vending. 

Lucia aspires to save enough money to secure the future of her family.

loans.use: to purchase more items to sell in her sari-sari store

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Jessa

texts.en:
Jessa L. is from the village of Malagana, Claveria, Misamis Oriental. She is 24 years old. Jessa is married and has one infant child. Jessa owns and operates a sari-sari (variety) retail shop. The main source of income for the business comes from buying and selling canned goods, junk food, biscuits, shampoo, soap & beverages in the local community. Jessa has been engaged in her business for over five years and earns approximately 10,000 Philippine pesos (PHP) a month from it.

In 2009, Jessa joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to do business. She has successfully repaid her last loan from HSPFI, which was for 10,000 PHP and was used to purchase additional inventory & working capital.

This loan will be her fifth from HSPFI. Jessa is requesting a new loan of 5,000 PHP which will be used to to purchase additional canned goods & junk food. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand it.

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional canned goods & junk food

loans.name: Yukuyoo Group

texts.es:
El nombre del grupo Yukuyoo se le denomina en lengua mixteca, que significa cerro D. bejucos (lianas), L. mayor parte D. esta población es D. raza indígena y se dedican a las labores del campo y a L. elaboración D. artesanías.
L. representante D. este grupo es L. señora Analidia Chávez D. L. C. quien vive en unión libre con el señor Silverio García quien se dedica a las labores del campo, tiene 2 niños que estudian L. primaria. Analidia se dedica a L. elaboración D. servilletas D. diferentes tamaños y D. distinto material D. hilos es una artesanía muy conocida por estas regiones. ElL. comenta que tiene buenas ventas y ésto le ha ayudado mucho para solventar los gastos D. su familia, pero ahora tiene un pedido y es por ello que solicitó el préstamo y con las ganancias que obtenga realizara sus pagos. Su más granD. anhelo es que sus hijos estudien, y poner una tienda D. artesanías en su localidad.
A continuación mencionare a las personas que integran este grupo y sus diferentes actividades:
Flora M.: Venta D. antojitos
Analidia C.: Elaboración D. servilletas
Gregoria N.: Venta D. dulces
Andrea L.: Elaboración D. servilletas
Herminia N.: Elaboración D. servilletas
Oliva V.: Venta D. antojitos
Herlinda L.: Elaboración D. servilletas
Eugenia Cantú: Venta D. comida
Lucia C.: Venta D. comida
Beatriz M.: Venta D. calzado
Catalina L.: Elaboración D. servilletas
texts.en:
The name of the Yukuyoo Group comes from the Mixteca language and means "liana-covered hill." The majority of the inhabitants are indigenous peoples who work the land or make traditional handicrafts for a living.

The group representative is Ms. Analidia C. D. L. C., who has a live-in partner, Mr. Silverio Garcia, a farmer. They have two children who currently attend elementary school. Analidia produces handmaD. napkins in different sizes and from different types of thread, a traditional craftwork that is well-known in this region. She states that sales are good, which is helping her cover the family expenses. Nevertheless, she now has an order to fill, so she is requesting this loan. She will make the repayments with her profits. Her greatest wish is for her children to get an education, and she hopes to set up a handicraft store in her community.

The following are the rest of the group members and their respective businesses: Flora M.: sells street food Analidia C.: produces handmaD. napkins Gregoria N.: sells candy Andrea L.: produces handmaD. napkins Herminia N.: produces handmaD. napkins Oliva V.: sells street food Herlinda L.: produces handmaD. napkins Eugenia Cantú: sells food Lucia C.: sells food Beatriz M.: sells footwear Catalina L.: produces handmaD. napkins

loans.use: to purchase thread for handmade napkins.

loans.name: Arsenia

texts.en:
Arsenia is 34 years old and married with one child.  Arsenia works very hard to provide for them.

Arsenia runs a sari-sari store -- a small variety store where she sells foodstuffs and household goods -- and has requested a 10,000 Philippine peso loan through Kiva field partner NWTF to purchase more stock to sell such as canned goods and other instant foods.  She has been in this business for three years.

In the future Arsenia would like to have enough money to be able to repair and renovate her home for her family.

loans.use: to purchase more stock, such as canned goods and other instant foods, to sell in a sari-sari store

loans.name: Ammie

texts.en:
Ammie is 31, married, and has one child who goes to school. She is a very hard working entrepreneur. 

Ammie has a RTW (ready-to-wear) clothing business in the Philippines. Ammie requested a 12,000 Philippine peso (PHP) loan through NWTF to buy more   RTW clothing to sell. 

Ammie has been in this business for two years. In the future, Ammie would like to build and expand her business to secure the future of her family.

loans.use: to purchase more clothes to sell

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Pinky

texts.en: Pinky T. is from the village of Tipolohon, Calaveria, Misamis Oriental. She is 34 years old. Pinky is widowed and has two school-aged children. To make a living, Pinky sells green and yellow bananas in the local community. Pinky has been engaged in her business for over five years and earns approximately 10,000 Philippines pesos (PHP) a month from it. Pinky joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Pinky has successfully repaid a previous loan of 6,000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to purchase additional inventory and as working capital. Pinky is requesting a new loan of 5,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional green bananas. This will be the third loan taken out by Pinky from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. About HSPFI: HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional green bananas

loans.name: Deogracia

texts.en:
Deogracia is 57 years old and married with six children. She is a very hard working entrepreneur. 

Deogracia has an RTW (ready-to-wear clothing) business in the Philippines. Deogracia requested a 13,000 Philippine peso (PHP) loan through NWTF to buy more clothes to sell. 

Deogracia has been in this business for two years. In the future, Deogracia would like to make some house improvements.

loans.use: to purchase more clothes to sell

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Rosalie

texts.en:
As a married parent of 3 children, Rosalie works hard to support her family.  She has a fish vending business in the Philippines, and also earns additional income from selling vegetables. Rosalie is borrowing PHP 15,000 through NWTF to buy more fish and spices to sell in her stall.

Rosalie has been sustaining her business activities through her past 11 loans from NWTF. She hopes that her hard work will help her attain her dream to build and expand her business in order to provide a secure future for her family.

loans.use: To buy more fish and spices to sell in her stall

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: El Progreso De La Amistad Group

texts.es:
La Sra. Priciliana es casada y tiene un hijo mayor D. edad, Priciliana es integrante D. la alcancía comunal 
“El Progreso D. la Amistad” grupo conformado por 13 socios que se dedican a actividades D. comercio, Priciliana se dedica a la elaboración y venta D. tejido desD. hace 3 años  y a su vez trabaja en  la venta y elaboración D. yogurt, este trabajo surge a raíz D. que  a su  esposo le diagnosticaron cáncer y el tratamiento D. su esposo era muy costoso, pero el deseo D. curar a su esposo no la detuvieron, es así que gracias a su esfuerzo y dedicación a conseguido mejores ingresos económicos, pueD. pagar el tratamiento D. su esposo y tiene una mejor calidad D. vida, ella  nos cuenta que le gustaría formalizar su negocio, el préstamo que  se le otorgo fue para comprar mercadería D. tejido y yogurt. Sabemos que Priciliana cumplirá sus metas con mucho trabajo y esfuerzo y que los préstamos D. Edaprospo la ayudaran.
texts.en: Ms. Priciliana is a married woman who has a grown son. Priciliana is a member of the El Progreso D. la Amistad community bank, which is comprised of 13 members who own small businesses. Priciliana has been making and selling knitwear for 3 years. At the same time, she also makes and sells yogurt. She launched this business because her husband was diagnosed with cancer, and the treatment is quite costly. However, her desire to cure her husband did not hold her back. Thus, due to her hard work and dedication, she has managed to obtain a better income, is now able to pay for her husband's treatment, and has a better quality of life. She states that she would like to make her business official. This loan is for purchasing knitted merchandise and yogurt. We know that Priciliana will reach her goals thanks to her hard work and efforts, and that these Edaprospo loans will help her.

loans.use: to purchase knitted merchandise and yogurt.

loans.name: Uzma's Group

texts.en:
Uzma lives in Faisalabad which is Pakistan’s third largest city, known for its textile industry. She lives there in a 2-room brick house with her family in the area of Madina Town. She moved here 6 years ago. She is 31 years old, married to S. Y. M., and has an 8-year-old daughter who is studying in class one. Uzma herself is illiterate but she is very sensitive about her daughter’s education. She wants her to complete her education and become successful in life. 

She is a very responsible person and as a wife she takes care of her family very well. Her husband is a government employee and earns a low income. Her brother also lives with her. He is 33 years old and operates a furniture showroom. He makes furniture and displays it in his showroom to attract customers and earn a profit. 

Uzma has applied for a loan from Kiva partner Asasah to financially assist her brother in his furniture business. Using the loan, he will buy wood, nails, a furniture polisher etc to make more furniture for sale. He has been operating this business for the past five years and Uzma is hopeful that an investment will help him complete orders on time and increase his profits. 

She is a new loan user and this is her first loan application with Asasah.  

Note: In the photo, the lady raising her hand is Uzma.

loans.use: To buy wood, nails and a furniture polisher for furniture-making business.

loans.name: Josefina

texts.en: Josefina D. is from the village of Victoria, Alicia, Isabela. She is 44 years old. Josefina is married and has five school-aged children. To make a living, Josefina runs a general store. The main source of income for the business comes from selling both food and daily-use products in the local community. Josefina has been engaged in her business for over 20 years and earns approximately 10,000 Philippines pesos (PHP) a month from it. In 2005, Josefina joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Josefina has successfully repaid a previous loan of 25,000 PHP from ASKI. This previous loan was used to purchase additional inventory and as working capital. Josefina is requesting a new loan of 30,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This will be the seventh loan taken out by Josefina from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. About ASKI: ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 38 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Jayson

texts.en:
Jayson P., from the village of District 1, is 29 years old and single. To make a living, for over three years Jayson has been raising pigs for fattening and sale. He earns approximately 3,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2011, Jayson joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Now requesting his first loan of 15000 PHP to purchase livestock feed and other supplies, he plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to financially support immediate members of his family.

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 38 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase livestock feed and other supplies

loans.name: Shakeela's Group

texts.en:
Shakeela comes from to Faisalabad which is located in Punjab, Pakistan and known for its textile industry. She has been living there with her family in the area of Madina Town in a 2-room brick house for the past six years. She is a working woman and does sewing work for her neighboring clients to share the financial burden with her husband. She has got that skill from her mother before marriage and it earns her good profits. 

She is also a very good housewife and manages her household responsibilities very well. She has given birth to three daughters. Two of them are studying while her youngest daughter is only six years old and has not started her education yet. 

Her husband’s name is A. M. and he operates a schoolbag-stitching business. He receives orders from different factories and fulfills their orders to earn income for the family. 

Shakeela has applied for a loan from Kiva partner Asasah to financially assist her husband’s business. Using the loan, he will buy a new machine for school-bag stitching. His current machine has become rough and needs replacement which is affecting his business. 

Shakeela is hopeful that her husband’s business will get well established after the loan investment and he will be able to provide his family better living facilities. She is a new loan applicant and this is her first loan application with Asasah.
 
Note: In the photo, the lady raising her hand is Shakeela.

loans.use: To buy a new machine for schoolbag-stitching business.

loans.name: Zubaida's Group

texts.en:
Zubaida comes from Faisalabad which is Pakistan’s 3rd largest city and famous for its textile industry. She has been living there in a 2-room brick house with her husband and children in the area of Medina Town for the past 35 years. 

She married Y. M. who is a daily wage laborer. His income is not enough for the whole family and that’s why Zubaida does sewing work for her neighborhood clients to help her husband financially. She is known as an expert in her work and receives a good number of orders every month. 

She also carries out her responsibilities as a housewife very well. She is the mother of five children, two sons and three daughters. Her two elder daughters left their education after the 8th class and started working. Both of them work in a factory on a monthly wage. Her remaining children are enrolled in a local school and getting their education. 

Zubaida has applied for a loan from Kiva partner Asasah for the improvement of her sewing business. Using the loan, she will buy a new sewing machine that will help her complete her work in a shorter period of time and earn better profits by producing quality work. She is hopeful that taking a loan from Asasah and investing in her business will be a good step towards a brighter future of her family. 

She is a new loan user of Asasah and this is her first loan application with Asasah. 

Note: In the photo, the lady raising her hand is Zubaida.

loans.use: To buy a new sewing machine for sewing business.

loans.name: Wilma Dinurog's Group

texts.en:
Mrs. Wilma D., a 46-year-old married resident of P2 Montol, Ozamiz City, is the group leader of this two-member group loan offered by PMPC. While each member receives an individual loan, each is responsible for paying back the loan of her fellow group member if she is delinquent or defaults. The official name of this borrowing group is Wima D.’s Group.

Wilma has been planting and harvesting corn for sale for 10 years, earning approximately 5,000 PHP a month. In April 2010, she joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. Having repaid her previous loan 7,000 PHP from PMPC that was used to purchase fertilizer, she is requesting her third loan of 10,000 PHP that will be used to pay for motor maintenance and corn fertilizer. Wilma plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family.

About PMPC:

Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to pay for motor maintenance and corn fertilizer

loans.name: Tasleem's Group

texts.en:
Tasleem lives in Faisalabad which is Pakistan’s third largest city and known for its textile industry. She resides in a 2-room brick house with her family in the area of Mian Pind. She moved here 15 years ago. She is 39 years old, married to M. J., and has six sons. Her three elder sons do different kind of work while younger ones are enrolled in a local school and are getting their education. 

Tasleem herself is an active and a responsible person by nature. She stays at home and carries out her responsibilities as a housewife very well. She makes the utmost effort to provide comfort to her family by fulfilling their needs. 

Her husband is a vegetable vendor. He put the vegetables on his cart and visits different streets of the city to sell them. Tasleem has applied for a loan from Kiva partner Asasah for the further expansion of her husband’s vegetable selling business. Using the loan, he will buy fresh seasonal vegetables for sale. He will also repair his cart because it has rotted in some areas which don’t carry vegetables. 

Tasleem hopes that this investment will bring positive changes to her husband’s business and his monthly income will grow up.  She is a new loan user and this is her first loan application with Asasah. 

Note: In the photo, the lady raising her hand is Tasleem.

loans.use: To buy fresh seasonal vegetables and repair his cart.
